definition: ψ, ψεῖ (q. v.), τό, indecl., twenty-third letter of the Ionic alphabet, Pl. Cra. 427a, Callias ap. Ath. 10.453d: not used in the Attic alphabet: in the Western Gr. alphabets it represents the sound χ ( kh): with the value ps it is found in SIG 1 ( Nubia, vi B. C.), etc.: as a numeral, ψʹ = 700, but ͵ψ = 700,000.
ψ ψ repeated, as exclamation, S. Ichn. 170.

children.definition: unguent; the following forms are found: Αἰγυπτίῳ ψάγδανι τρὶς λελουμένη Eub. 102; φέρʼ ἴδω, τί σοι δῶ τῶν μύρων; ψάγδαν φιλεῖς; Ar. Fr. 206; σάγδαν ἐρυγγάνοντα Eup. 198; βάκκαρίς τε καὶ σάγδας ὁμοῦ Epil. 1: ψάδᾳ (sic codd.) is cited by Erot. fr. Hp. (not found in codd. Hp.), and fr. Eup. ( Fr. 198?): nom. ψαγδης (unaccented) Ath. 15.690e, cf. ψαγδῆς, Hsch. (Egypt. sgnn with or without prefixed masc. Art. p;).

data.quote: φέρʼ ἴδω, τί σοι δῶ τῶν μύρων; ψάγδαν φιλεῖς;

children.definition: oblique, askew, metaph., mal à propos, blundering, εἰ πὰρ μέλος ἔρχομαι ψάγιον (sic codd. vett.) ὄαρον ἐννέπων Pi. N. 7.69: ψάγιον· πλάγιον, λοξόν, ἐπικεκλιμένον, Hsch.; ψάδιον· κάταντες, Id.

definition: ψάδδα ἡ κινάβαρις, Hsch. ψαδυρός, v. ψαθυρός.

children.definition: scratch, rub, σὺ δὲ τὴν κεφαλὴν ψάθαλλέ μου scratch my head, Hermipp. 78, cf. Pl.Com. 59.
Sammelb. 5124.332 (ii A. D.).
crumble away, Aq. Jo. 9.5(11), Ps. 101(102).4.

friable, crumbling, of the roe in fish, Arist. HA 510b26; ἰχθῦς . . τοὺς σαρκώδεις καὶ ψ. Diocl. Fr. 141; opp. γλίσχρος, Arist. Mete. 387a15; of bread, Gal. 6.523; of cheese, opp. κολλώδης, ib. 698 ( Comp.); of meat, Ruf. ap. Orib. 4.2.8 ( Comp.); τὸ ὕδωρ ψ. Arist. Sens. 441a25; of air, Id. de An. 419b35; of earth, Thphr. CP 2.4.11, Nic. Al. 145; γῆ -ωτέρα Gp. 3.3.10; of the texture of some bulbs, Thphr. HP 7.9.4; of leaves in a salad, Hp. Liqu. 5 ( Comp.); also ψαδυρόν· ἀσθενές, μαδαρόν, ψαθυρόν, Hsch. (the form is Att. acc. to Gal. 16.760), and ψαθαρά· εὔθλαστα, etc., Hsch.; cf. ψαφαρός.
looseness of consistency, Arist. HA 524b26, Pr. 928a10, Gal. 6.799.

definition: ψαιδρά ἀραιότριχα, Hsch.: ψαιδρόν· φαιδρόν, . . , Id. (Cypr. acc. to Et.Gud. 572.53). ψαιθόν· ὑποφοινίσσον, Hsch. ψαικάζει· ῥα<ί>νει, Id. ( ψακ- poscit ordo). ψαίκαλον· ἔμβρυον, βρέφος, Id. (leg. ψακ-).
ψαικαλοῦχον ἔμβρυον, Hsch. ψαῖμα· ὀλίγον Id.; cf. ψαῖσμα.
ψαινούζειν διὰ ῥ.πισμοῦ καταψύχειν. γὰρ δὲ καὶ δραπισμοῦ, Hsch. (Fort. ψαινυθίζειν· διὰ ῥιπισμοῦ κ., γρ (άφεται) δὲ καὶ διὰ πρισμοῦ καταψήχειν.)

children.definition: false, vain, Hsch.:— Lyc. 1420 has ψαίνυνθα θεσπίζειν prophesy falsely (formed like μίνυνθα).

definition: ψαινῦντες ψωμίζοντες, Hsch. ψαίνυον· ἀχρεῖον, Id. ψαινύροιτο· διεσείσατο, Id. ψαίνυσμα· ὀλίγον, Id.; cf. ψαῖσμα.
ψαίρω, only pres., and not in Att. Prose: (v. ψάω):

children.label: I
children.definition: graze, brush lightly, touch gently, οἶμον αἰθέρος ψαίρει πτεροῖς . . οἰωνός is ready to skim the path of ether, A. Pr. 396; rub, scrape gently in washing, Eun. VS p.486B.

children.label: II
children.definition: move lightly or quiver, flutter, palpitate, of an irregular pulse and the like, Hp. Mul. 2.120: hence, rustle, murmur, of the rustling of leaves in the breeze, Luc. Trag. 315; of stars, twinkle, Nic. Th. 123.
ψαίρειν λέγομεν τὸ ἱστίον ὅταν ἐλαφρῶς διαπνέηται Hsch. s.v. διαψαίρουσι.

data.quote: ψαίρειν λέγομεν τὸ ἱστίον ὅταν ἐλαφρῶς διαπνέηται

definition: ψαῖσμα σῖτον ὀλίγον, Hsch., cf. ψαῖμα, ψαίνυσμα.
ψαιστίον, Dim. of ψαιστόν, AP 5.16 ( Gaet.), dub. in IG 5(1).1447 ( Messene, iii/ii B. C.).

children.definition: ground, ψ. μᾶζα a cake of ground barley mixed with honey and oil, Hp. Int. 20; ψαιστόν, τό (sc. πέμμα or πόπανον), a cake of this kind, used at sacrifices, Ar. Pl. 138, 1115, Antiph. 206.3, Com.Adesp. 372, Thphr. ap. Porph. Abst. 2.15, SIG 1038.18 ( Eleusis, iv/iii B. C.), Herod. 4.92, AP 6.190 ( Gaet.), 191 ( Corn.Long.): perh. to be written ψᾳστός, cf. ψᾷστον· σὺν τῷ ῑ, ἐκτείνουσι τὸ ᾱ, ὡς Εὐφρόνιος, Lex.Mess. p.411: v. ψαστής.
like a ψαιστόν, AB 313.
one that wipes off, σπόγγος AP 6.295 ( Phan.).
rub away, grind down, in aor. 1 Med., Thphr. ap. Porph. Abst. 2.6:— aor. Pass., ibid.
Dim. of ψακάς, drizzle, Polioch. 2.5, Thphr. CP 2.9.3.
spotted, dappled, of a mare, prob. in PPetr. 2p.115 (ii B. C.).
with dappled haunches (?), of horses, PPetr. 2p.115 (ii B. C.).

rain in small drops, drizzle, drip, Ar. Nu. 580: impers., ψακάζει it drizzles, ψακαζέτω ἄρτοισι let it rain loaves, Nicoph. 13:— Med., εἰκάζουσι . . λύχνῳ ψακαζομένῳ μύωπα they liken a short-sighted person to a spluttering (i. e. dying) lamp, prob. in Arist. Rh. 1413a4 (cf. Anon. in Rh. 217.3; εἰς μύωπα codd., εἰς secl. Buhle):— Pass., ψεκασθέντα moistened with slight rain, Thphr. CP 6.19.5.
new-born animal, Ar.Byz. ap. Eust. 1625.48; ψάκαλος, ὁ, Id. ap. Ael. NA 7.47: ψαίκαλον in cod. Hsch. (From ψακάς; for the sense cf. δρόσος, ἕρση.)
having young, μητέρες ψ. mothers with their young, S. Fr. 793 (anap.); cf. ψαικαλοῦχον.

definition: ψακάς, Ion. and later (cf. Moer. p.419P.) ψεκάς, άδος, ἡ:—

children.definition: drop of rain, ὅταν μὲν κατὰ μικρὰ φέρηται, ψακάδες, ὅταν δὲ κατὰ μείζω μόρια, ὑετὸς καλεῖται Arist. Mete. 347a11, cf. 348a7, al.; particle, ib. 373b16: mostly collect., drizzle, ψακὰς δὲ λήγει, i. e. heavy rain ( ὄμβρος) is coming, A. Ag. 1534 (lyr.); opp. ὑετοί, X. Cyn. 5.4 (pl.); ὕσθησαν αἱ Θῆβαι ψακάδι Hdt. 3.10: generally, rain, ὑπὸ στέγῃ πυκνῆς ἀκοῦσαι ψακάδος S. Fr. 636, cf. E. Hel. 2, Ar. Th. 856; so ψεκάς Hp. Epid. 2.3.1: ψεκάδες showers, Gal. 17(1).37; also φοίνισσα ψακάς a shower of blood, Simon. 106; βάλλει μʼ ἐρεμνῇ ψακάδι φοινίας δρόσου A. Ag. 1390; Βρομίου ψακάδεσσι, i.e. drops of wine, Critias 1.10.

data.quote: ὅταν μὲν κατὰ μικρὰ φέρηται, ψακάδες, ὅταν δὲ κατὰ μείζω μόρια, ὑετὸς καλεῖται
βάλλει μʼ ἐρεμνῇ ψακάδι φοινίας δρόσου

children.definition: a sputterer, Ar. Ach. 1150 (lyr.), cf. Suid. s.v.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἀργυρίου μηδὲ ψακάς not a drop of money, Ar. Pax 121; [ψάμμου] ψεκάς grains of sand, AP 12.145. ( ψακάς prob. by assimilation from ψεκάς.)
dripping, μύρον Ephipp. 26.
Dim. of ψακάς, small piece or drop, Hsch. ψάκτα, ἡ, a kind of cake, Id. ψακτήρ, ῆρος, ὁ, = ψήκτρα, Id. (perh. for *ψηκτήρ).

definition: ψαλάθριον, dub. l. in AP 7.472.11 ( Leon.).
ψαλάκανθα [ᾰκ], ἡ, name of a fabulous plant, Eub. 28 (hex.), Ptol. Heph. ap. Phot. Bibl. p.150B. (Ptol.Cyther., Suid.).
ψαλάκιος, ὁ, perh. an occupational name, dub. in PLond. 3.604.40 (i A. D.).

children.definition: to be touched, dub. in Hsch.; cf. ἀψάλακτος.
touch lightly, Ael. NA 3.18; ψ. κτύπον νευρᾶς make a string sound by touching it, Lyc. 139:— aor. 1 Med. in Hsch.
pair of scissors, POxy. 1289.5,6 (v A. D.).
Scissors, nickname of Alexander Logotheta, because he clipped the coins, Procop. Arc. 26, Goth. 3.1.
like a vault or arch, Ph. Bel. 81.35, Gal. UP 8.11.
nipper-mouthed, Com. epith. of crabs, Batr. 295.
vault, arch, Bito 54.7 ( Pass.).
vault, CIG 4385 ( Isauria, ii A. D.); ψ. καμαρωτά Str. 16.1.5, cf. Gloss.
arched, vaulted, ἱππαφέσεις D.H. 3.68.
clip with scissors, l.c., Archig. ap. Orib. 8.2.10, Antyll. ap. eund. 7.21.6; τὸν μαλλὸν ἐψάλιζεν Babr. 51.4, cf. Aesop. 382b: ψαλίξαι· κεῖραι, Hsch.

definition: ψάλιον, τό, part of the bridle,

children.definition: curb-chain, ῥυταγωγέα . . ἐκ τοῦ ψ. ἠρτημένον X. Eq. 7.1; τὸ περὶ γένειον διειρόμενον, ψάλιον Poll. 1.148; = κρίκος τοῦ χαλινοῦ, Sch. E. Ph. 792: freq. in pl., because the curb-chain was formed of links, which rattled as the horse moved, χρυσοχάλινον πάταγον ψαλίων Ar. Pax 155 (anap.); ψαλίων κρότον καὶ χαλινοῦ κτύπον Ael. NA 6.10; ψαλίοις ἐδάμασε πώλους E. HF 381 (lyr.): metaph., οἷον ψ. αὐτῇ [τῇ βασιλείᾳ] ἐνέβαλε τὴν τῶν Ἐφόρων δύναμιν Pl. Lg. 692a.

data.quote: οἷον ψ. αὐτῇ [τῇ βασιλείᾳ] ἐνέβαλε τὴν τῶν Ἐφόρων δύναμιν

children.definition: chain, bond, A. Pr. 54 (pl.): metaph., μέγα δʼ ἀφῃρέθη ψ. οἰκετῶν Id. Ch. 962 (lyr.).
βορινοῦ καὶ νοτινοῦ ψαλίου (or Ψαλίου) the N. and S. ring (or Ring), in description of an estate, POxy. 1632.12 (iv A. D.).
jaw, Hippiatr. 28 (cf. ψέλιον, ψάλλιον).
a pair of scissors, among the toilette articles of a lady, Ar. Fr. 320.1, S. Fr. 413 (nisi leg. ψέλια), PTeb. 331.13 (ii A. D.); δρεπάνοισι καὶ οὐ ψαλίδεσσι καρῆναι AP 11.368 (Jul.Antecessor).

children.label: b
children.definition: razor, expld. by μιᾷ μαχαίρᾳ (v. μάχαιρα), Poll. 2.32, 10.140.

children.label: II
children.definition: sewer, drain, στενὴν δʼ ἔδυμεν ψαλίδα S. Fr. 367; vault, crypt, ψαλίδαπρομήκη λίθων ποτίμων Pl. Lg. 947d; barrel-vault, Supp.Epigr. 2.582 ( Ionia, iii/ii B. C.), Explor.Arch. de Délos 11.262, Ph. Bel. 80.46 (pl.), Hero *Stereom. 2.28; ἀνήγειρεν τὴν ψ. ταύτην Supp.Epigr. 2.755 ( Syria, ii A. D.); Gal. compares the fornix ( ψαλιδοειδές) of the brain to a ψ. οἰκοδομήματος σφαιροειδοῦς, 2.725; similarly the arch of the foot, UP 3.8; having keystones ( ὀμφαλοί), Arist. Mu. 399b30; and being curved ( καμφθεῖσα), Str. 17.1.42 (dub.), D.S. 2.9; expld. by καμάρα and ἁψίς, Sch. Pl. l.c., Suid.; as entrance and exit of a theatre, LW 1586 (Aphrodisias, written ψελίς).

children.label: III
children.definition: αἱ ψ. τῶν στύλων prob. the rounded mouldings between the capital and the column, LXX Ex. 27.10, 11; so perh. ψαλλίδες in BGU 1028.9 (ii A. D.).
rings for the staves of the altar of incense, LXX Ex. 30.4; iron bands for strengthening an engine, Ph. Bel. 57.33.

children.label: IV
children.definition: Pl. Lg. 947d.
clipping, Archig. ap. Orib. 8.2. 5.
one must clip, Antyll. ap. Orib. 45.24.10.
clipped, Hierocl. p.54A., Antyll. ap. Orib. 8.5.1, Aët. 3.129.
sprung from harp-playing, Com. epith. of Archytas, strictly a parody of Homerʼs μοιρηγενής, Bion ap. D.L. 4.52.
chain, PLond. 3.1177.234 (ii A. D.).

definition: ψάλλω, fut. ψᾰλῶ LXX Jd. 5.3, 1 Ep.Cor. 14.15: aor. ἔψηλα Pl. Ly. 209b, etc., and in LXX ἔψᾱλα Ps. 9.12, al.:—

children.definition: pluck, pull, twitch, ψ. ἔθειραν pluck the hair, A. Pers. 1062: esp. of the bow-string, τόξων χερὶ ψάλλουσι νευράς twang them, E. Ba. 784; κενὸν κρότον Lyc. 1453; ἐκ κέραος ψ. βέλος send a shaft twanging from the bow, APl. 16.211 (Stat. Flacc.); so μιλτοχαρὴς σχοῖνος ψαλλομένη a carpenterʼs red line, which is twitched and then suddenly let go, so as to leave a mark, AP 6.103 ( Phil.): metaph., γυναῖκας ἐξ ἀνδρῶν ψόγος ψάλλει, κενὸν τόξευμα E. Fr. 499.

data.quote: γυναῖκας ἐξ ἀνδρῶν ψόγος ψάλλει, κενὸν τόξευμα

children.label: II
children.definition: play a stringed instrument with the fingers, and not with the plectron, ψῆλαι καὶ κρούειν τῷ πλήκτρῳ Pl. l.c., et ibi Sch.; ἐάν τις ψήλας τὴν νήτην ἐπιλάβῃ Arist. Pr. 919b15; μουσικώτατος ὢν χατὰ χεῖρα δίχα πλήκτρου ἔψαλλε Ath. 4.183d; opp. κιθαρίζω, Hdt. 1.155, SIG 578.18 ( Teos, ii B. C.); πρὶν μέν σʼ ἑπτάτονον ψάλλον (sc. τὴν λύραν) Ion Eleg.3.3: abs., Hdt. l.c., Ar. Eq. 522, Hippias (?) in PHib. 1.13.24; κόραις Men. Epit. 260; ψάλλειν [οὐκ ἔνι] ἄνευ λύρας Luc. Par. 17:—Prov., ῥᾷον ἤ τις ἂν χορδὴν ψήλειε ‘as easy as falling off a log’, Aristid. Or. 26(14).31.

data.quote: ἐάν τις ψήλας τὴν νήτην ἐπιλάβῃ
μουσικώτατος ὢν χατὰ χεῖρα δίχα πλήκτρου ἔψαλλε

children.definition: sing to a harp, LXX Ps. 7.18, 9.12, al.; τῇ καρδίᾳ Ep.Eph. 5.19; τῷ πνεύματι 1 Ep.Cor. l.c.
Pass., of the instrument, to be struck or played, ψαλλομένη χορδή Arist. Pr. 919b2; also of persons, to be played to on the harp, Macho ap. Ath. 8.348f.
tune played on a stringed instrument, AP 11.34 ( Phld.), Max.Tyr. 37.4.
sing psalms, and ψαλ-μιστής, οῦ, ὁ, psalmist, Gloss.
twitching or twanging with the fingers, ψαλμοὶ τόξων E. Ion 173 (lyr.); τοξήρει ψαλμῷ [τοξεύσας] Id. HF 1064 (lyr.).

children.label: II
children.definition: πηκτίδων ψαλμοῖς κρέκον ὕμνον Telest. 5, cf. Diog.Trag. 1.9, Aret. CA 1.1.

the sound of the cithara or harp, Pi. Fr. 125, cf. Phryn.Trag. 11; ψαλμὸς δʼ ἀλαλάζει A. Fr. 57.7 (anap.); there were contests in τὸ ψάλλειν, Michel 898.10 ( Chios, ii B. C.), 913.6 ( Teos, ii B. C.).
song sung to the harp, psalm, LXX 2 Ki. 23.1, al., Ep.Eph. 5.19; βίβλος ψαλμῶν Ev.Luc. 20.42.
delighting in harp-playing, of Apollo, AP 9.525.24.
singing to the harp, Aristid. 2.310J.
psalmist, LXX Si. 47.9 cod.Sin., 50.18.
Philostr. VA 6.10.
stringed instrument, psaltery, harp, τρίγωνα ψ. Arist. Pr. 919b12, cf. Hippias(?) in PHib. 1.13.31, Apollod. ap. Ath. 14.636f, Thphr. HP 5.7.6, LXX Ge. 4.21, al., Jul. Or. 2.49c.

harper, Men. 495, Hippias (?) in PHib. 1.13.7, 25, Macho ap. Ath. 8.348f, LXX 1 Es. 5.42, Plu. Adul. 2.67f, Apophth. Lac. 223f, cf. κιθαριστὴς ἢ ψ. SIG 578.15 ( Teos, ii B. C.); epith. of Apollo, AP 9.525.24. [Oxyt. in Att., parox. in Hellenistic Gr., Choerob. in Theod. 1.187H.]
Hsch., Suid.
of or for harp playing, ψ. ὄργανον a stringed instrument, Ath. 14.634f (of the μάγαδις) ; ἄνδρα ψαλτικὴν ἀγαθόν a good harpist, Ael. ap. Ar.Byz. Epit. 84.8.
sung to the harp, sung of, LXX Ps. 118(119).54.
female harper, Pl. Prt. 347d, Ion Trag. 22, Arist. Ath. 50.2, Men. 319.4, Plu. Caes. 10, al.
sing to the harp, LXX 2 Ch. 5.13.

definition: ψαλύγων ἔνιοι ψάλυγας τὰς λεγομένας ψυχάς, ἄμεινον. καὶ τοὺς ἀσθενεῖς σπινθῆρας, Hsch. (cf. φεψάλυξ).

children.definition: sandy, Nic. Th. 887.
sandy seashore, Hsch.

definition: ψαμαθίς, ῖδος, ἡ, a sea-fish, elsewh. ὗς, Numen. ap. Ath. 7.327a.
ψάμαθος, ἡ (poet., also in a Homeric paraphrase, Plu. E apud Delph. 2.393e),

children.definition: sand of the sea-shore, ἔρειπε δὲ τεῖχος Ἀχαιῶν . . , ὡς ὅτε τις ψάμαθον πάϊς ἄγχι θαλάσσης . . συνέχευε Il. 15.362; ψαμάθῳ εἰλυμένα πολλῇ Od. 14.136; ἀμφὶ χλωρὰν ψ. S. Aj. 1064; παρακτία ψ. E. IA 165 (lyr.), cf. 1054 (lyr.); παρὰ ψ. καὶ θῖνʼ ἁλός Ar. V. 1520 (lyr.): freq. in pl., νῆα . . ἐπʼ ἠπείροιο ἔρυσσαν ὑψοῦ ἐπὶ ψαμάθοις Il. 1.486; ἐπὶ ψαμάθοις ἁλίῃσι Od. 3.38, cf. 4.438; of river-sand, Il. 21.202, 319.

data.quote: ἔρειπε δὲ τεῖχος Ἀχαιῶν . . , ὡς ὅτε τις ψάμαθον πάϊς ἄγχι θαλάσσης . . συνέχευε
νῆα . . ἐπʼ ἠπείροιο ἔρυσσαν ὑψοῦ ἐπὶ ψαμάθοις

children.definition: ὅσα ψ. τε κόνις τε ib. 9.385: pl., grains of sand, φύλλοισιν ἐοικότες ἢ ψαμάθοισιν 2.800; ὁπόσαι ἐν θαλάσσᾳ καὶ ποταμοῖς ψάμαθοι κλονέονται Pi. P. 9.47. (Perh. formed by combining ψάμμος and ἄμαθος; similarly ἄμμος ( ἅμμος) by combining ἄμαθος and ψάμμος; ἄμαθος is cogn. with Engl. sand.)

data.quote: ὁπόσαι ἐν θαλάσσᾳ καὶ ποταμοῖς ψάμαθοι κλονέονται

children.definition: sandy, χῶρος h.Merc. 75, al., cf. A.R. 4.1376, etc.

definition: ψάμμα, ατος, τό, in pl. ψάμματα· σπαράγματα, Hsch.

children.definition: sandy, Inscr.Prien. 326.2.

sand-hundred, Com. word formed from ψάμμος after the analogy of διακόσιοι, τριακόσιοι, etc., to denote a countless multitude, ψ. θεαταί Eup. 286 ( ψαμμοκ- v.l. ap. Suid.), cf. Ath. 15.671a; also ὀνόματα ψ. grandiloquent terms, Id. 6.230d.—So the exaggerated form ψαμμᾰκοσιογάργᾰροι, αι, α, Ar. Ach. 3 (v.l. ψαμμοκ-): cf. γάργαρα.
Hsch.
ψάμμος, Hdt. 4.181 (v.l. ψάμμος), who elsewh. always has the common form: Dor. ψάμμα A. Pr. 573 (lyr.), Ar. Lys. 1261 (lyr.).
cake, Harp. s.v. Ἑκάτης νῆσος.
of the size of a grain of sand, μέγεθος Olymp. in Phd. p.31 N.

definition: ψαμμίας ἀκάτα corrupt in A. Ag. 985 (lyr.).

children.definition: of sand, sandy, Hdt. 2.99, Philostr. Her. 3.4.
grain of sand: in pl., of gravel in urine, Ruf. Ren.Ves. 3.6, 11, Aret. SD 2.3, Alex.Aphr. Pr. 1.110.
burying in sand, Paul.Aeg. 3.78.19 (pl.).
from sand, δόρπος AP 9.551 ( Antiphil.).
ἀριθμός) name of a treatise ( Arenarius) by Archimedes.

children.label: II
children.definition: ὗς ψαμμῖτις
sand-eel, Archestr. Fr. 22.2.
with a sandy soil, Hdn. Epim. 208.
sand-diver; name of a fish that buries itself in the sand, elsewh. καλλιώνυμος, Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: mole, Cyran. 78.
like sand, sandy, Hp. Nat.Hom. 14.

definition: ψάμμος, ἡ, but in Archim. Aren. 1.1, al., always ὁ:—

children.definition: sand, used by Hom. for ψάμαθος only in Od. 12.243, later very freq., Hdt. 8.71, etc.: pl., grains of sand, αἱ ἀπʼ ἀλλήλων ἐσκεδασμέναι ψάμμοι S.E. P. 1.130: prov., ψάμμος ἀριθμὸν περιπέφευγεν Pi. O. 2.98; οἶδα δʼ ἐγὼ ψάμμου τʼ ἀριθμόν Orac. ap. Hdt. 1.47; ἐκ ψάμμου σχοινίον πλέκειν, of labour in vain, Aristid. 2.309J.; of something worthless, LXX Wi. 7.9, D.Chr. 77/8.30; ψάμμου ἄξιον Oenom. ap. Eus. PE 5.21.
Olymp.Alch. p.106B., Zos.Alch. p.239 B.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἡ ψ. the sandy desert of Libya, the sand, Hdt. 3.25, 4.173; πλείστης ψάμμου OGI 666.27 ( Egypt, i A. D.). (Prob. *ψαφ-μος, cf. ψαφαρός, ψῆφος, Lat. sabulum.)
art of extracting gold from sand, Zos.Alch. p.241B.
sandy, Hdt. 2.32, Aen.Tact. 8.2: τὰ ψ. sandy sediment in the urine, gravel, Hp. Aph. 4.79, Gal. 6.571; called ψ. ὑποστάσεις by Id. 17(1).836.
of plaster or stucco, κόσμος τοίχου LXX Si. 22.17.

definition: ψάρ, ὁ, gen. ψᾱρός: pl. ψᾶρες: Ion. ψήρ, ψηρός, ψῆρες:—

children.definition: starling, Sturnus vulgaris, ὥς τε ψαρῶν νέφος . . ἠὲ κολοιῶν Il. 17.755; ἴρηκι ἐοικὼς ὠκέϊ, ὅς τʼ ἐφόβησε κολοιούς τε ψῆράς τε 16.583; ψῆρες, dat. ψήρεσι, Q.S. 8.387, 11.218; ψᾶρες Antiph. 302 (anap.), AP 9.373, Gal. 6.567; Plu. Sollert. 2.972f mentions their being taught to speak, cf. Gell. 13.21 (20).25.

data.quote: ὥς τε ψαρῶν νέφος . . ἠὲ κολοιῶν
ἴρηκι ἐοικὼς ὠκέϊ, ὅς τʼ ἐφόβησε κολοιούς τε ψῆράς τε

definition: ψάρις γένος στρουθοῦ, Hsch.; also εἶδος νεὼς τριήρους, Id. ψαρίχοι ( -ίγχοι cod.): ψᾶροι, Id.

children.definition: battle of the starlings, Suid. s.v. Ὅμηρος.
Arist. HA 617b26; gen. pl. ψάρων Gal. 6.435.

like a starling, i.e. speckled, dappled, ψ. ἵππος a dapple-grey horse, Ar. Nu. 1225, LXX Za. 1.8; Arist. HA 632b19 distinguishes it fr. ποικίλος, which implies that the spots are more distinctly marked:— Comp. ψαρότερος Ael. NA 12.28, Aët. 11.11.

definition: ψαρός (B), ά, όν, neut. ψαρόν, τό, name of a siccative powder, Paul.Aeg. 7.13.11; perh. cf. ψηρός.
ψαστής τὰ ψαιστὰ ῥόδα, Hsch. (Perh. ψᾴστʼ ἦς (i. e. ψαιστὰ ἦν) , Ῥόδιοι.)
ψατᾶσθαι προκαταλαμβάνειν, Hsch.: ψατῆσαι· προειπεῖν, Id. (Prob. cogn. with φθάνω.)
ψαυκροπόδης, ὁ, and ψαυκρόποδα (acc. sg. masc.),

children.definition: swift-footed, epith. of the horse Arion, EM 817.45, Hsch.

definition: ψαυκρός, ά, όν, in neut. ψαυκρὸν γόνυ· κοῦφον, ἀπὸ τοῦ ἄκρως ψαύειν, Hsch.; also ψαυκρός· καλλωπιστής, ταχύς, ἐλαφρός, ἀραιός, Id.: cf. σαυκρός.
ψαῦος, sine expl., Alcm. ap. Sch.A Il. 12.137.
ψαύριος or ψαυρός, ὁ, acc. to Hsch.

children.definition: touching, contact, Democr. 11, Plu. QConv. 2.683c, Sor. Fract. 13, Gal. 18(2).786:—esp. of lovers, caress, φιλήματων καὶ ψαύσεως Plu. Alc. 4, cf. 2.768b.
touch, caress, X.Eph. 3.2.
one must touch, Antyll. ap. Orib. 10.23.23.
touched, ἄγαλμα οὐδὲ ψ. χειρὸς ἀνθρωπίνης, i. e. not made by mortal hand, Hdn. 1.11.1.

definition: ψαύω, Ep. impf. ψαῦον Il. 13.132; ψαύεσκον ( ἐπι-) Orph. L. 126: fut. ψαύσω A. Ch. 182, etc.: aor. ἔψαυσα Pi. N. 5.42, etc.: pf. ἔψαυκα ( παρ-) S.E. M. 7.116:— Pass., aor. ἐψαύσθην Dsc. 2.14: pf. ἔψαυσμαι ( παρ-) Hp. Morb. 4.44:—

children.definition: touch, τινος Il. 23.519, 806, Hdt. 2.47. etc.; ἁπτόμενοι καὶ ψ. ἀλλήλων in close contact, Plu. Pyrrh. 12: metaph., μὴ ψαύειν ἀδικίας ὃν τρόπον οὐδὲ πυρός Phld. Rh. 2.155S.: c. dat. instr., ψαῦον . . κόρυθες . . φάλοισι the helmets touched with their φάλοι, Il. 13.132, 16.216; τῇ κεφαλῇ τοῦ οὐρανοῦ ψ. Hdt. 3.30; χεροῖν . . ἔψαυσα πηγῆς A. Pers. 202; εἰ τῆσδε χώρας μήποτε ψαύσει ποδί Id. Ch. 182: but the dat. is used for the gen. in Pi. P. 9.120, Herod. 4.75, Q.S. 8.349 (cf. θιγγάνω II.3, προσψαύω):— ψαύω never takes acc. exc. in αἵματι ψαῦσαι θύρας Ezek. Exag. 158: in S. Ant. 857, ἔψαυσας ἀλγεινοτάτας ἐμοὶ μερίμνας, πατρὸς τριπόλιστον οἶκτον (v.l. οἶτον) , μερίμνας is gen. sg. and οἶκτον or οἶτον is acc. depending on ἔψαυσας . . μερίμνας, = ἐποίησάς με μεριμνᾶν; and ib. 961, κεῖνος ἐπέγνω μανίαις ψαύων τὸν θεὸν ἐν κερτομίοις γλώσσαις, the construction is ἐπέγνω τὸν θεόν, ψαύων (sc. αὐτοῦ) he learned to know the god, assailing (him): later writers used the Pass. as if the Act. had a trans. sense, Dsc. l.c., Plu. Frig. 2.951d.

data.quote: μὴ ψαύειν ἀδικίας ὃν τρόπον οὐδὲ πυρός
εἰ τῆσδε χώρας μήποτε ψαύσει ποδί

children.definition: touch lightly. a way of feeling the pulse, opp. θλίβω, Gal. 8.808: metaph., touch upon a subject, notice it slightly, Plb. 1.13.8:— Med., c. acc. rei, touch lightly upon a subject, Gal. 18(1).331.
touch as an enemy, lay hands upon, τινος E. IA 1559: abs., κλάοις ἄν, εἰ ψαύσειας A. Supp. 925, cf. S. OC 856.
touch, affect, οὐ γὰρ ἄκρας καρδίας ἔψαυσέ μου E. Hec. 242.

data.quote: οὐ γὰρ ἄκρας καρδίας ἔψαυσέ μου

children.definition: reach, gain, ὕμνων Pi. N. 5.42; ψ. Ἀφροδίτας Id. O. 6.35: abs., hit the mark, AP 7.428.11 ( Mel.).
ἐπίπεδα ψαύοντα tangent planes, Archim. Con.Sph. 17.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., to be touched, of the star-fish, ἐνδίδωσι τὸ σῶμα καὶ περιορᾷ ψαυόμενον ὑπὸ τῶν παρατρεχόντων Plu. Sollert. 2.978b, cf. Frig. 951d (if the comma be placed before, not after, οὐσίας) ; ὅσοι ὑπὸ τῶν Ἀμινναίων (sc. οἴνων) ψαύονται κεφαλῆς those who are affected in the head . . , Dsc. 5.19.—The word is very rare in early Prose, Antipho 3.3.5, X. Mem. 1.4.12: freq. later, Plb. 1.13.8, al., Plu. Gen.Socr. 2.589f, al.

data.quote: ἐνδίδωσι τὸ σῶμα καὶ περιορᾷ ψαυόμενον ὑπὸ τῶν παρατρεχόντων

definition: ψᾶφαξ, ακος, Aeol. for ψῆφος, Greg.Cor. p.623 S.

children.definition: dust, dirt, Dsc. 1.97 (v.l. ψαθ-).
AP 12.192 ( Strat.).
with dry, rough hair or coat, μῆλα h.Pan. 32.

definition: ψαφαρός, ά, όν, Ion. ψαφερός, ή, όν, Hp. (v. infr.):—

children.definition: friable, powdery, crumbling, σποδός A. Th. 323 (lyr.), cf. Euph. 50; κόνις AP 7.315 ( Zenod. or Rhian.); ψαφαρόν, = ἁπαλόν, perh. of a fine powder, Pl.Com. 118: freq. of soil, sandy, λεπτόγεως καὶ ψ. χώρα Thphr. HP 8.2.11; opp. ἀγαθή, ib. 8.9.1 ( Comp.); ἡ ψαφαρή the sandy shore, opp. ἅλς, AP 12.145; ἐνὶ ψαφαρῇ Σαλαμῖνι Euph. 30.
of loose texture, of the glands, the brain, Hp. Gland. 1, 10, Sor. 1.12 ( ψαθ- cod.), al.
thin, watery, διαχώρημα Hp. Coac. 596; νάρδος AP 6.231 ( Phil.); πόλτος ψαφαρώτατος Sor. 1.51 ( ψαθ- cod.).
rough, dry, joined with ἀλιπής, Gal. ap. Ath. 1.26d, cf. ψαθυρός.
χροιὴ ψ. dry, dusty-looking, Nic. Th. 262.—Cf. ψαθυρός fin.
become disintegrated, Olymp. Alch.p.94B.
PSI 8.892 (iv A. D.), restd. fr. Hsch. s.v. φυκιοχαίτης.
rough on the surface, squalid, κάρα E. Rh. 716 (lyr.).

definition: ψαφερός, ή, όν, Ion. for ψαφαρός (q. v.). ψάφιγμα, v. ψήφισμα.

children.definition: Aeol. for ψῆφος, κρύπτᾳ ψάφιγγι IG 12(2).526 a.16 ( Eresus, iv B. C.), cf. EM 554.52.

definition: ψάω [ ᾱ, but always contracted], ψῇ S. Tr. 678, inf. ψῆν ( περι-) Ar. Eq. 909: impf. contr. 3 sg. prob. ἀπέψη (v. ἀποψάω): fut. ψήσω ( ἀπο-) Id. Lys. 1035: aor. ἔψησα Hippon. 12 Diehl, A.R. 3.831, ( κατ-, περι-) Pl. Phd. 89b, Ar. Pl. 730:— Med., freq. in compos. with ἀπό:— Pass., aor. ἐψήθην ( συν-) LXX Je. 31(48).33 (v.l. -ψήσθ-) ; ἐψήσθην ( ἀν-) BGU 530.17 (i A. D.): pf. ἔψησμαι ( παρ-) Poll. 4.152. Later authors sts. use the contr. by ᾱ instead of η, inf. ἀνα-ψᾶν Dsc. 4.64:—

children.definition: rub, wipe, τίς ὀμφαλητόμος σε . . ἔψησε κἀπέλουσεν; Hippon. l.c.; polish, PHolm. 3.19; rub smooth, αὐσταλέας δʼ ἔψησε παρηΐδας A.R. l.c.; of solderers, PLond. 3.1177.285 (ii A. D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: crumble away, vanish, disappear, S. Tr. 678 (s. v. l.). ( ψάω, ψαίω, ψαύω, ψαίρω, ψήχω, ψώχω, and perh. ψίω, ψωμός, seem to be different enlargements of ψ-, which corresponds to ps- in Skt. psā ´ti, bhes- in Skt. babhasti ‘crush, chew, devour’, bhasman ‘ashes’.)

definition: ψε, v. σφεῖς A. II. ψεαυτόνς, v. σφεῖς A. II.
ψέγω (A), S. OT 338, etc.: fut. ψέξω Pl. Grg. 518d: aor. ἔψεξα Thgn. 611, S. Aj. 1130, Pl. Lg. 634c, etc.:— Pass., pf. ἔψεγμαι Hp. Acut. 51:—

children.definition: blame, censure, τινα Thgn. l.c., A. Ag. 186 (lyr.), 1403; τι S. OC 977, etc.; λόγον δοῦναι . . περὶ ὧν ψέγουσι Pl. Tht. 177b; διά τι Id. Prt. 346c; ἐπί τινι X. HG 6.5.49: c. acc. rei, τὸ . . διδάσκειν Id. Eq. 6.5: c. dupl. acc., τίς ποτʼ ἐστὶν ὅν γʼ ἐγὼ ψέξαιμί τι; S. OC 1172; ἃ ψέγομεν τὸν Ἔρωτα Pl. Phdr. 243d; ταὐτὰ ψέγων καὶ ἐπαινῶν Id. Grg. 510c, cf. Lg. 634c; ψ. τινὰ ὅτι . . , εἰ . . , Isoc. Ep. 2.15, X. HG 6.5.51; τινα c. inf., Pl. R. 404d: c. acc. cogn., ψ. ψόγους Id. Grg. 483c:— Pass., ἡ ἐπιείκεια οὐ ψέγεται there is no objection to it, we find no fault with it, Th. 5.86; ψέγεται ὡς τοιοῦτον ὄν Pl. R. 358a; ψεγ[όμενα], of damaged goods, prob. in Supp.Epigr. 7.417.18 ( Dura, iii A. D.).

data.quote: τίς ποτʼ ἐστὶν ὅν γʼ ἐγὼ ψέξαιμί τι;

definition: ψέγω (B), in compd. ἐπιψέγω (q. v.), cf. ψέγος.

children.definition: sparse-haired, bald, Tz. H. 7.891.
bald-headed, Orph. L. 253.
become bald, S.E. M. 1.255.

thin, spare, scanty, λάχνη Il. 2.219; χαῖται AP 9.430 ( Crin.); κόμαι Aret. SD 2.13: later of a person, bald-headed, Luc. DMort. 30[25].1: generally, bare, naked, χωρία Aristid. Or. 36(48).67 ( Comp.):—v. l. for ψυδρός or ψυδνός in Thgn. 122.
baldness, Adam. 2.37.
A. Supp. 1042 (lyr.), Hsch.
Hsch.: cf. ψιδόνες, ψυθῶνες.

definition: ψεῖ, τό, name of the letter ψ, Hellad. ap. Phot. Bibl. p.530 B.

children.definition: Hdn. Gr. ap. Orion Lex. col.168: but ψιάω is thus glossed in An.Ox. 1.401.

definition: ψεκάζω, ψεκάς, later forms for ψακ-, q.v.

children.definition: one must blame, τι Plu. Aud.poet. 2.27b.
ψεκτέος, α, ον, to be blamed, S.E. M. 2.105.
censurer, faultfinder, Hp. Acut. 6, Pl. R. 589c, Lg. 639c.
censorious, Arist. Rh.Al. 1421b9, Poll. 5.117; τὸ -κόν Stoic. 2.62. Adv. -κῶς Poll. 5.118.
blameworthy, opp. ἐπαινετός, Pl. Cra. 416c, Arist. EN 1108a16, Plb. 3.4.1, etc. Adv. -τῶς Poll. 4.26 (s. v. l.).

definition: ψέλιον, later sts. ψέλλιον ( v. l. in X. Cyr. 1.3.2, never in Hdt.), POsl. 46.8 (iii A. D.), Supp.Epigr. 7.428 ( Dura, iii A. D.), in Inscrr. ψίλιον, ψίλλιον (qq. v.), τό:—

children.definition: armlet or anklet, ψέλιον περὶ ἑκατέρῃ τῶν κνημέων Hdt. 4.168; mostly in pl. ψέλια, a favourite ornament of the Persians, Id. 3.20, 22, 9.80, X. An. 1.2.27, Cyr. 1.3.2; worn by women in Egypt, BGU 1101.8 (i B. C.), POxy. 259.11 (i A. D.), etc., and in Greece, Plu. Coniug. 2.142c.
PCair.Zen. 782 ( a). 42 (iii B. C.); ψελίου καὶ δρεπάνου PPetr. 2p.113 (iii B. C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: οἱ Δωριεῖς ψέλλιον καλοῦσι τὸ ἄκρον· ὅθεν καὶ ἡμεῖς τὴν ἐπʼ ἄκρων χειλέων λεγομένην προσῳδίαν ψιλὴν ἐκαλέσαμεν, ὥς φησι Τρύφων Ammon. Diff. p.143V. ( ψέλιον is distd. from ψάλιον by Ammon. Diff. p.142 V., Ptol.Asc. p.396H., but is the later form of ψάλιον acc. to Moer. p.420P., Sch. E. Ph. 792 ( ἔστι δὲ ψέλιον ὁ κρίκος τοῦ χαλινοῦ, ἢ ἁπλῶς ὁ κρίκος) and this may be the meaning in PCair.Zen. l.c.)

data.quote: οἱ Δωριεῖς ψέλλιον καλοῦσι τὸ ἄκρον· ὅθεν καὶ ἡμεῖς τὴν ἐπʼ ἄκρων χειλέων λεγομένην προσῳδίαν ψιλὴν ἐκαλέσαμεν, ὥς φησι Τρύφων

children.definition: armlet-maker, Gloss. ( ψελοπ- cod.).
wearing bracelets, Hdt. 8.113.
twine, wreathe, ψ. αὐχένα στεφάνοις AP 7.234 ( Phil.).
Med., put on an armlet, ψελιουμένη subject of statue by Praxiteles, Plin. HN 34.70.

falter in speech, speak inarticulately, like a child, ψ. καὶ τραυλίζουσι Arist. HA 536b8:—so in Med., Pl. Grg. 485b, 485c; ψελλίζονται καὶ τραυλίζουσι ( -ονται Bonitz), τοῦτο δʼ ἐστὶν ἔνδεια τῶν γραμμάτων Arist. PA 660a26; ψελλιζόμενος τὴν Ἑλλάδα φωνήν Hld. 8.15: metaph., of Empedocles and the early philosophers, speak indistinctly, ἃ ψελλίζεται λέγων Ἐμπεδοκλῆς Arist. Metaph. 985a5; ψελλιζομένῃ ἔοικεν ἡ πρώτη φιλοσοφία περὶ πάντων ib. 993a15; of metals, hesitate to alloy, Id. GC 328b9:— Act. is later in this sense, used of Aristotle, Phld. Rh. 2.51S.

data.quote: τοῦτο δʼ ἐστὶν ἔνδεια τῶν γραμμάτων

children.definition: ψελλιζόμενος ἐς τὰ πολεμικά, of a boy soldier, Philostr. Her. 19.2.
necklace or armlet, PPar. 9.14 ( ii B. C., pl.).
inarticulate speech, of a childʼs attempts at talking, Him. Or. 23.21; of a nurseʼs ‘baby-talk’, Sor. 1.109 (pl.).
stammering, ψελλισμοὶ γλώσσης Plu. QConv. 2.650e.

children.label: II
children.definition: indistinctness, ib. Comm.not. 1066d, ποδάγρας ψ. unpronounced ( i.e. suppressed) gout, Plu. Sull. 26.
stammerer, Gloss.

children.label: II
children.definition: ψελλισταὶ οἱ λεγόμενοι Hippiatr. 10 (v.l. ψυλλισταί, κονδυλισταί).
faltering in speech, like a child; distd. fr. τραυλός (lisping), Arist. HA 492b32, Pr. 902b22; τὸ ψ. prob. in Phld. Rh. 2.206S.; ἡ ψελλὴ οὐ πιττεύω (i. e. πιστεύω) Suid., App.Prov. 3.17.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass. of words, inarticulate, obscure, unintelligible, A. Pr. 816; ψελλόν ἐστι καὶ καλεῖ τὴν ἄρκτον ἄρτον Com.Adesp. 393.

data.quote: ψελλόν ἐστι καὶ καλεῖ τὴν ἄρκτον ἄρτον

children.definition: imperfect pronunciation, distd. fr. τραυλότης by Arist. Pr. 902b24; ψ. γλώσσης ἰδία νόσος Plu. Sollert. 2.963c.
= 1/3 of a γράμμα II 5, Hero *Geom. 23.61.
blame, Gloss.

definition: ψέτ, dub. sens., ἰς τὸ ψέτ, item in household accounts, PGoodsp.Cair. 30 xxx 4, al. (ii A. D.).

children.definition: to be a false messenger (and false angel), Ph. 1.273; cf. sq. [ψευδαγγελής]
Ar. Av. 1340 codd. ( ψευδαγγελήσειν Bentl.).
false report, X. Eq.Mag. 5.8, D.C. 49.28.
bringing a false report, lying messenger, Il. 15.159; Ὀδυσσεὺς ὁ ψ., title of play, Arist. Po. 1455a14.
pretend ignorance falsely, dissemble, D.C. 44.38.
bastard ἄγχουσα, Plin. HN 22.50.
false brother, pretended Christian, 2 Ep.Cor. 11.26, Ep.Gal. 2.4, Gloss.
in false Aeolic, of dialect, Choerob. in Theod. 1.262H.
lying braggart: as Adj., ψ. λόγοι Com.Adesp. 294.
sham-Alexander, an impostor pretending to the name, J. AJ 17.12.2, Luc. Ind. 20.
false, counterfeit, Nonn. D. 8.325: so ψευδάλμιον· ψευδές, Hsch.
bastard vine, Ar. V. 326 (anap.).
pseudo-Antoninus, D.C. 78.32.
sham man, epith. of Dionysus, Polyaen. 4.1.
false ambassador or apostle, 2 Ep.Cor. 11.13.
false silver, i. e. perh. zinc, Str. 13.1.56.
false number, Sch. Pl. Tht. 191b.
fallacy, in pl. title of work by Euclid, Procl. in Euc. p.70F., cf. p.59 F.
a pretended follower of Aristophanes, Ath. 1.5b.
Ar. Ach. 91, 99 ( False-measure, cf. ἀρτάβη).
false orach, Com. name of a plant in Ar. Eq. 630; cf. ψευδαμάμαξυς.
false Attic, Luc. Sol. 7, Phryn. 48.
sham desertion, Polyaen. 3.9.32.
sham deserter, X. Eq.Mag. 4.7.

definition: ψευδεγγραφῆς γραφή, ἡ, an action brought by a citizen

children.definition: to show that he has been wrongly entered in a list of debtors, an action for false entry, Arist. Ath. 59.3, cf. Lycurg. Fr. 12; Ἀναψυκτίδου διώξαντος ψευδεγγραφὴν ὦφλεν κτλ. IG ΙΙ(2).146 B 29 ( Delos, iv B.C.), cf. Inscr.Délos 399 A 98 (ii B.C.).
falsely entered, bogus, Senatus consultum Cic. Att. 15.26.1.
feigned ambuscade, X. An. 5.2.28, Eq.Mag. 5.8.
false ( i.e. forbidden) seizure of security, prob. in PHal. 1.241 (iii B.C.).
Hsch.
with false superscription or title, not genuine, D.H. Dem. 57, Inscr.Prien. 37.123 (ii B.C.); φιλόσοφος Plu. Frat. 2.479e; τρόπος superficial, Plb. 23.5.5.
pretending to be good, Heph.Astr. 2.2 (in Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(2).58).
a false, illegal guardian, Plb. 15.25.1.
falsely ascribed to Epicharmus, Ath. 14.648d.
feigned attack, Polyaen. 3.9.32.
speak falsely, A. Pr. 1032, E. Fr. 396, Philem. 102.5; ὅσσα . . -έουσιν ἀοιδοί Opp. C. 4.319; τὰ ἄλλα . . ἐψευδηγόρηται PMag. Leid.V. 10.8.
false discourse, lying, Alciphr. 1.18.
speaking falsely, lying, Lyc. 1455.
Luc. Ocyp. 63:— ψευδηλόγος, ον, = ψευδολόγος, gloss on ψευδηγόρος, Lex. in An.Bachm. 1.419, v.l. in Suid. s.v. ψευδηγόρος.

definition: ψευδήμων, ον, gen. ονος, poet. for ψευδής, Nonn. D. 8.39, AP 15.1.

children.definition: sham-Hercules, name of a Comedy by Menander, Plu. Adul. 2.59c, Ath. 4.172a.
cenotaph, Lyc. 1048,1181.

definition: ψευδής, ές (the neut. sg. ψευδές is not found in early writers, ψεῦδος being used instead, cf. ψεῦδος III; it is found in later Gr., OGI 669.54 ( Egypt, i A.D.), Palaeph. 6, al., Gal. 18(2).782); gen. sg. ψευδοῦς Id. 15.168; old Att. acc. pl. ψευδᾶς IG 1(2).700: ( ψεύδομαι):—

children.definition: lying, false, untrue, of things, opp. ἀληθής, ψ. λόγοι Hes. Th. 229; μῦθοι A. Pr. 685, E. Hipp. 1288 (anap.); τρέπεσθαι ἐπὶ ψευδέα ὁδόν to betake oneself to falsehood, Hdt. 1.117; ψ. κατηγορία, αἰτίαι, false charges, Aeschin. 2.183, Isoc. 15.138, Plb. 5.41.3; λόγοι S. OT 526; λόγος Pl. Sph. 240e, Cra. 385b: ψ. λόγοι are also fallacies, in Logic, Arist. Top. 162b3 sqq.; ἥδε ἡ ψ. οὐσία this unreal Being (sc. the world of sense), Plot. 5.8.9: irreg. Sup. ψευδίστατος, εἴδη Ael. VH 14.37.

lying, false, and as Subst., liar, οὐ γὰρ ἐπὶ ψευδέσσι πατὴρ Ζεὺς ἔσσετʼ ἀρωγός Il. 4.235 (only here in Hom.; perh. ψεύδεσσι from ψεῦδος is the true accent; so Hermappias ap. Hdn.Gr. 2.45 against Aristarch. and Ptol.Asc. ibid.); τοὺς θεοὺς ψευδεῖς τίθης S. Ph. 992, cf. Ant. 657; ψ. ἔφυς E. Or. 1608; ψ. φανήσεσθαι to be detected in falsehood, Th. 4.27, cf. Pl. Tht. 148b; Κριτίαν ψευδῆ ἐπιδείξω Id. Chrm. 158d: irreg. Sup. ψευδίστατος arrant liar, EM 110.29, cf. Eust. 1441.25.

data.quote: οὐ γὰρ ἐπὶ ψευδέσσι πατὴρ Ζεὺς ἔσσετʼ ἀρωγός

children.definition: τὰ ψευδῆ falsehoods, lies, οὐ ψευδῆ λέγω A. Ag. 625, cf. Antipho 1.10, etc.; οὐκ ἔσθʼ ὅπως λέξαιμι τὰ ψευδῆ καλά A. Ag. 620; τινὰς ψ. διαβάλλειν Ar. Eq. 64; ψευδῶν συγκολλητής Id. Nu. 446 (anap.).

data.quote: οὐκ ἔσθʼ ὅπως λέξαιμι τὰ ψευδῆ καλά

children.definition: ψευδέων ἀγορή, in Hp. Epid. 3.1.ηʹ, ιβʹ, said to be a name of the monkey-market, perhaps as being villanous counterfeits of humanity.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., beguiled, deceived, E. IA 852.

children.label: III
children.definition: Adv. ψευδῶς falsely, λέγειν Id. IT 1309 codd.; προσποιήσασθαι Th. 1.137; mistakenly, ψ. δοξάζειν Pl. Phlb. 40d; ψ. γενέσθαι τὸν φόβον groundlessly, Plb. 5.110.7.
falsely ascribed to Hesiod, Cic. Att. 7.18.4.
false priest, J. AJ 9.6.6, al.

definition: ψεῦδις, ιος, ὁ, ἡ, poet. word,

children.definition: built of equal blocks, but in courses of unequal size, Vitr. 2.8.5.
pretended help, X. Eq.Mag. 5.8, Polyaen. 3.9.32.
Cretan pimpinell, Pimpinella cretica, Dsc. 4.124, Plin. HN 24.153.
to be elated on unreal grounds, Tz. H. 4.720.
Phryn. PS p.127B.
give a fallacious proof, Arist. Top. 101a10:— Pass., ib. 132a33, 160b36.
write false accounts or statements, PEnteux. 63.18 (iii B.C.), Plb. 12.7.6, 16.14.8, PTeb. 78.17 (ii B.C.).
false diagram, fallacious proof, Arist. SE 171b12 (pl.), Alex.Aphr. in Top. 22.20, in SE 76.23.

definition: ψευδογραφία, ἡ, = foreg., in pl., Ps.- Archyt. ap. Stob. 1.41.5, Quint. Inst. 1.10.39.

children.definition: false account, Ath. 5.216b.
a drawer of false diagrams, Arist. SE 171b35, al.
writer of falsehoods, Thom.Mag. p.224 R.: = falsarius, Gloss.
false, unreal repast, A. Fr. 258 (pl.).
pretending to skill in dialectics, Gal. 8.629.
false teacher, 2 EP.Petr. 2.1.
θύραι sham double doors, PMich.Zen. 38.33 (iii B.C.).
false dittany, Ballota acetabulosa, Hp. Nat.Mul. 32, Thphr. HP 9.16.2, Dsc. 3.32.
false dipteral, of a temple in which there is only one row of columns along the sides, though there is space left for two, Vitr. 3.2.1.
entertain a false opinion or notion, Epicur. Fr. 253, Plb. 10.2.3, 16.12.11, Phld. Ir. p.76W., Ph. 1.363, J. AJ 9.4.3.
false opinion or notion, Polystr. p.14 W., Phld. D. 1.14 (pl.), Str. 14.5.28, Plu. QConv. 2.716b, Hierocl. in CA 12p.446M., etc.
holding a false opinion or notion, labouring under a delusion, Gal. 19.484.
Polyaen. 3.9.32.
speak falsely, Jul. Gal. 351c.
secret door, LXX Bel 15; Dim. ψευδο-θύριον [ῠ], τό, ib. 21.
false ( i.e. secret) door, Cic. Verr. 2.2.20, al., Gloss.
narrate falsely, Eust. 363.28.
spurious cassia, Str. 16.4.14, Dsc. 1.13, Gal. 14.258.
accuse falsely, Cod.Just. 1.4.34.17.
false accusation, Man. 4.332, Vett.Val. 231.1, Heph.Astr. 2.28 ( Cat. Cod.Astr. 8(2).94).
false accuser, slanderer, Hsch. s.v. ἀνάδικοι, Cat.Cod.Astr. 7.112.
false, lying herald, S. Ph. 1306.
spurious cinnamon, Dsc. 1.14 ( -κινά-), Gal. 12.26.

the offence of falsely subscribing oneʼs name as witness to a summons ( κλητήρ) , γραφὴ ψευδοκλητείας a prosecution for such false subscription, D. 53.17, Arist. Ath. 59.3; βαδίζειν ἐπί τινα τῆς ψευδοκλητείας D. 53.15; ψευδοκλητείας τρὶς ὀφλεῖν And. 1.74.—This is the form found in Arist. l.c. (Pap.), in the best codd. of D. and in Poll. 8.40, 44; ψευδοκλητία is found in codd. of And. and as v.l. in D.; ψευδοκλησία in Harp. (with vv.ll. -κλητία, -κληστία, -κλησις), Suid.
one who falsely subscribes his name as witness to a summons, Theopomp.Hist. 267.

definition: ψευδοκορα, dub. (perh. incomplete) in Ostr.Bodl. iii 295 (i A.D.).

children.definition: a pretended maid, Poll. 4.151.
bastard κύπειρος, Dsc. 5.75.15; pseudocypirus Plin. HN 17.95.
sham Cynic, Plu. Brut. 34.
silly falsehood, Tz. H. 10.868.
sham robber, name of a Comedy by Timocles.

definition: ψευδόλιτρος, ον, Att. for ψευδόνιτρος: ψ. κονία lye or soap

children.definition: made from adulterated soda, Ar. Ra. 711 (lyr.).
speak falsely, spread false reports, Isoc. 10.8, Aeschin. 2.119, etc.; give a wrong account, Phld. Sign. 21.
false statement, lie, Sch.Par. A.R. 4.57.
falsehood, Isoc. 12.1, D. 35.32, etc.: pl., Isoc. 12.78, Thphr. Char. 8.15.
lying, false, Proll.Hermog. in Prolegomenon Sylloge p. 282 Rabe.

definition: ψευδολογιστής, οῦ, ὁ, = sq., name of a treatise by Lucian.

children.definition: speaking falsely, lying, Ar. Ra. 1521 (anap.); ὁ ψ. Plb. 31.22.9, cf. Phld. Po. 5.14, Gal. Anim.Pass. 2.2, etc.; σοφίης AP 9.80 ( Leon.).
false prophet, Hdt. 4.69, A. Ag. 1195, S. OC 1097, E. Or. 1667, etc.
false Marius, App. BC 3.2.
IG 5(2).357.5,6 ( Stymphalus, iii B.C.).
to be a false witness, bear false witness, Critias 61, Pl. R. 575b, X. Mem. 4.4.11, Arist. Rh. 1375a12; κατά τινος LXX Ex. 20.16, Ev.Marc. 14.56.

false witness, D. 41.16 codd.; ψευδομαρτυρίαν καταγνῶναί τινος Is. 12.6 codd.: ἐν ψευδομαρτυρίαις D. 57.53 codd.: but mostly in gen. pl., ψευδομαρτυριῶν διάκρισις Pl. Lg. 937b; -ιῶν δίκη Is. 3.6; κρίσεις Arist. Pol. 1263b21; -ιῶν ἑλεῖν τινα to convict, and ἁλῶναι to be convicted, of perjury, Is. 5.15, And. 1.7, Lys. 10.25, Aeschin. 1.85; ὀφλεῖν And. 1.74; -ιῶν ἐπισκήψασθαί τινι make allegation of perjury against one, D. 29.7; etc. (This form is perh. always corrupt in codd. of classical authors; -ίων (gen. pl. neut., cf. sq. [ψευδομαρτυρίου]) shd. prob. be read for -ιῶν, and may be restored for -ίαν in D. 41.16, Is. 12.6; so -ίοις for -ίαις in D. 57.53: των ψευδομαρτυριων is unaccented in Pap. of Hyp. Phil. 12: ψευδομαρτυρια[ν is an uncertain restoration in IG 5(2).357.3 ( Stymphalus, iii B.C.); but the fem. form existed later, Ev.Matt. 15.19, 26.59.)
for false witness or perjury, Cratin. 454, PHal. 1.24, 41, 49, al. (iii B.C.); in dat. pl., ἔνοχος τοῖς ψευδομαρτυρίοις Pl. Tht. 148b; acc. pl. τὰ -μαρτύρια Arist. Ath. 59.6.

false witness, pl. in Gorg. Pal. 23, Pl. Grg. 472b, Critias 61: sg., IG 5(2).357.4 ( Stymphalus, iii B.C.): ψευδομάρτυρες τοῦ θεοῦ false witnesses about God, 1 Ep.Cor. 15.15; as Adj., τὰν δίκαν τὰν ψευδομάρτυρα the action for false witness, IG l.c. l. 8; ψ. τιμαί honours attesting no real merit, Plu. Praec. 2.821f.
lavender spike, Lavandula spica, Plin. HN 12.43.
dreaming a false dream, Charito 3.7.
a false Nero, Luc. Ind. 20.
a false, feigned marriage, E. Hel. 883.
false, sham education, Cebes 11, Gal. 6.633.
false Pan, Jul. Or. 7.234d.
pretended panic, terror, Polyaen. 3.9.32.
use of words of similar sound but different meanings, Eust. 29.40.
pretended maid or virgin, Hdt. 4.180; as Adj., ψ. ἑταίρα Ach.Tat. 8.3.
false pavement or floor, Cod.Just. 8.10.12.3a.
false, unnatural father, Call. Cer. 99.
with false peristyle, of a temple in which the columns on the sides are attached to the walls instead of standing free, Vitr. 4.8.6.
false πίθος, i.e. of a different capacity from the official πίθος, BCH 50.214 (Thasos, v. B.C.).

definition: ψευδοπλάνης [ᾰ], ητος, ὁ, and ψευδο-πλᾰνήτης, ου, ὁ, prob.

children.definition: lying vagrant, Eust. 1762.2, 1742.23, of Odysseus.
forger of lies, Sch. Ar. Nu. 445.
feigned to be rich, Sch. Ar. V. 457.
misrepresent, τὰ εὐεργετήματα . . τῶν ἄλλων ἐπειρᾶτο ψευδοποιεῖν καὶ ταπεινοῦν Plb. 30.4.13.

data.quote: τὰ εὐεργετήματα . . τῶν ἄλλων ἐπειρᾶτο ψευδοποιεῖν καὶ ταπεινοῦν

children.label: II
children.definition: give the lie to, expose as false, τὰς ἀποφάσεις τῶν ποιητῶν Id. 12.25.4, cf. 12.25c.3, S.E. M. 24; folld. by acc. et inf., stigmatize as false the doctrine that . . , Phld. Rh. 2.87S.

children.label: III
children.definition: Pass., to be deceived or mistaken, err, αἴσθησις -εῖται Placit. 4.9.5.
pretended little town, J. BJ 4.9.9.
sham purple garment, POxy. 1051.15 (iii A.D.).
false ambassador, Sch. S. Ph. 1306.
pretended treachery, Polyaen. 3.9.32.
pretended traitor, Polyaen. 6.38.7.
false, lying prophet, J. AJ 9.6.6, al., 2 Ep.Pet. 2.1, Ph. 2.343, etc.
sham or unfair fall from which one starts up again and renews the contest, Plu. Comp.Pel.Marc. 1, Sch. Ar. Eq. 568, Macar. 8.88.
pretended beggar, Eust. 1761.54.
false watch-fires, Suid., Macar. 8.86.
false rhapsodist, Hsch., as gloss on ψευδοραβδοθίαι (sic).
swear falsely, Ar. Ec. 603 (anap.); distd. fr. ἐπιορκεῖν by Chrysipp.Stoic. 2.63.
perjury, Ph. 2.196.
perjured, forsworn, Hdt. 1.165.

definition: ψεύδορκος, ον, = foreg., E. Med. 1392 (anap.), Ps.-Phoc. 17: Sup., Ph. 1.412.
ψευδορρήμων, ον, gen. ονος, τὰ ψ.

children.definition: false locutions, perh. made-up words, Phld. Po. 2.41.

definition: ψεῦδος, εος, τό, Ep. dat. pl. ψεύδεσσι,

children.definition: ψεύδω):— falsehood, lie, ψεύδεα . . ἐτύμοισιν ὁμοῖα Od. 19.203, Hes. Th. 27; ψεῦδός κεν φαῖμεν Il. 2.81; ψεῦδος δʼ οὐκ ἐρέει Od. 3.20; εἴ τε ψεῦδος ὑπόσχεσις εἴ τε καὶ οὐκί whether the promise be a lie or no, Il. 2.349; οὔτι ψεῦδος ἐμὰς ἄτας κατέλεξας 9.115; ψεύδεσσιν θέλγειν τινά 21.276, cf. 23.576, Od. 14.387; οὐ ψεύδεϊ τέγξω λόγον Pi. O. 4.19; ψ. ποικίλα, αἰόλον ψ., Id. O. 1.29, N. 8.25; ψ. γλυκύ a sweet deceit, Id. P. 2.37; ψεῦδος οὐδὲν ὧν λέγω S. El. 1220; οὐδὲν ἕρπει ψ. εἰς γῆρας χρόνου Id. Fr. 62; εἴ τι ψεῦδος εἴρηκα Antipho 3.4.2; ψ. ἐπιφέρειν Aeschin. 3.41: ψ. λέγειν distd. fr. ψεύδεσθαι, Stoic. 2.42.

data.quote: οὐδὲν ἕρπει ψ. εἰς γῆρας χρόνου

children.definition: false conclusion, fallacy, συλλογισμὸς τοῦ ψεύδους Arist. APr. 61b3; συμβαίνει ψ. ib. 37a36:—in NT of what is opposed to religious truth, false doctrine, Ep.Rom. 1.25; ποιῶν βδέλυγμα καὶ ψ., i.e. doing what is repugnant to the true faith, Apoc. 21.27; of false anatomical doctrine, τὸ οἴεσθαι . . ψ. ἐστι Sor. 1.17.

children.label: II
children.definition: Theoc. 12.24 ψεύδεα are spots, pimples on the nose; supposed to be characteristic of liars, cf. Sch. ad loc.; cf. ψυδράκιον.
white spots on the fingernails, Alex.Aphr. Pr.Anecd. 2.58.

children.label: III
children.definition: Pl. ψεῦδος is freq. opp. ἀληθές, Grg. 505e, R. 382d, Euthd. 272b, al.; so almost like an Adj. (cf. ψευδής init.), ὄνομα ψεῦδος καὶ ἀληθὲς λέγειν Cra. 385c; παράδοξόν τε καὶ ψεῦδος ὄνομα Plt. 281b: cf. E. Heracl. 462 codd.
false moonlight, absence of the moon, Hsch., Suid.
false wisdom, and ψευδόσοφος, ον, falsely wise, Philostr. VA 8.7.
sham-sophist, name of a treatise by Lucian.
a false or pretended στιγματίας, name of a play by Nicostr.Com.
the false or blind mouth of a river, Str. 17.1.18 (pl.).
speak falsely, S. OC 1127, Luc. Ocyp. 8.
having false or blind mouths, name of a river in India, Ptol. Geog. 7.1.8, al.; ψ. στόμα = ψευδόστομα, ib. 4.5.5, 3.10.2, al.: hence τὸ Ψ. as pr. n., D.S. 20.75.
a false writer, Tz. in An.Ox. 3.332, and ψευδο-συγγρᾰφέω, write falsely, Id. H. 8.185.
false wasp, a solitary kind, Plin. HN 30.98.
Philostr. VA 8.31.
false, spurious art, Sch. Aphthon. in Rh. 2.623 W., Serv.Dan.ad Verg. Aen. 1.464.
falsely reckoned the thirteenth, Tz. H. 2.505.
one who practices deceitful arts, Pl. Sph. 241b.
shining with false, i.e. borrowed, light, of the moon, D.L. 2.1.
falsely uttered, S. OC 1517.
a false Philip, Luc. Ind. 20.
false Christs, Ev.Matt. 24.24.
a false chrysolite, D.S. 2.52 ( ψευδοχρυσολίθους cj. Salmasius).
of mock gold, Plu. Adul. 2.50a.
falsely held to be supposititious; ὁ Ψευδυπ. name of plays by Crobylus and Cratin.Jun.

definition: ψεύδω, S. Ant. 389, etc.: fut. ψεύσω Id. OC 628, X. Cyr. 1.5.13: aor. ἔψευσα A. Pers. 472, Plb. 18.11.11, etc.:— Pass., fut. ψευσθήσομαι S. Tr. 712, Gal. 15.143: aor. ἐψεύσθην Hdt. 1.141, etc.: pf. ἔψευσμαι (v. infr.); imper. ἐψεύσθω Aeschin. 1.162:—

children.definition: cheat by lies, beguile, τινα S. OC 628, etc.:— Pass., to be cheated, deceived, A. Ch. 759, etc.; εἰ μὴ πολύ γε ἔψευσμαι unless I am much deceived, Antipho 3.2.1.

cheat, balk, disappoint one of a thing, ψεύσει σʼ ὁδοῦ τῆσδʼ ἐλπίς E. Hec. 1031; ἔψευσας φρενῶν Πέρσας A. Pers. 472; μὴ ψεῦσον Ζεῦ τῆς ἐπιούσης ἐλπίδος Ar. Th. 870; πιστεύω . . μὴ ψεύσειν με . . τὰς ἐλπίδας X. Cyr. 1.5.13; πόλλʼ ἐλπίδες ψεύδουσι καὶ λόγοι βροτούς E. Fr. 650:— Pass., to be cheated balked, disappointed, τινος of a thing, ψευσθῆναι ἐλπίδος, γάμου, Hdt. 1.141, 5.47; ἐνάρων S. Aj. 178 (lyr.); δείπνου Ar. Nu. 618 (troch.); ψευσθέντες τῶν σκοπῶν disappointed of receiving tidings from the scouts, Th. 8.103.

data.quote: μὴ ψεῦσον Ζεῦ τῆς ἐπιούσης ἐλπίδος
πιστεύω . . μὴ ψεύσειν με . . τὰς ἐλπίδας
πόλλʼ ἐλπίδες ψεύδουσι καὶ λόγοι βροτούς

children.definition: Pass., also, to be deceived, mistaken in or about a thing, ἐψευσμένοι γνώμης deceived in their judgement, mistaken in opinion, Hdt. 8.40, cf. S. Tr. 712 (also ψευσθῆναι γνώμῃ Hdt. 7.9.γʹ); ἐψευσμένοι τῆς Ἀθηναίων δυνάμεως deceived or mistaken in their notions of the Athenian power, Th. 4.108; πολλῶν ἐψεύσθητε τῆς οὐσίας you have often had a mistaken idea of a manʼs wealth, Lys. 19.45; τούτου οὐκ ἐψεύσθην Pl. Ap. 22d; ἐψεῦσθαι τῆς ἀληθείας Id. R. 413a; τῆς ὥρας And. 1.38; ἐψευσμένοι τῶν ὄντων Pl. Tht. 195a; ἐψεῦσθαι ἑαυτῶν, opp. εἰδέναι ἑαυτούς, X. Mem. 4.2.26; also ψευσθῆναι ἔν τισι Hdt. 9.48; περί τινος X. An. 2.6.28, Pl. Prt. 358c: also c. acc., ἐψεύσθη τοῦτο X. An. 1.8.11, etc.; αὐτοὺς ἐψευσμένη ἡ Ἑλλάς deceived in its estimate of them, Th. 6.17 (where αὐτοὺς is prob. corrupt, and shd. perh. be omitted): c. acc. cogn., εὐτυχέστατον ψεῦσμα ἐψευσμένος most happily deceived or mistaken, Pl. Men. 71d: more rarely in Act., καί μʼ ἔψευσας ἐλπίδος πολύ thou hast much belied my expectation, i.e. turned out better than I feared, S. Aj. 1382.
to be untrue, ἡ τρίτη τῶν ὁδῶν μάλιστα ἔψευσται the third mode of explanation is most untrue, most mistaken, Hdt. 2.22.

children.label: II
children.definition: represent a thing as a lie, falsify, ψεύδοντες οὐδὲν σῆμα τῶν προκειμένων S. OC 1512 (prob. for σημάτων) ; ψεύδει ἡ πίνοια τὴν γνώμην afterthought gives opinion the lie, Id. Ant. 389:— Pass., ἢν τάδε ψευσθῇ λέγων if his word prove (lit. be proved) false, Id. Ph. 1342; ἡ ψευσθεῖσα ὑπόσχεσις the promise broken, Th. 3.66; πάντα πρὸς ὑμᾶς ἔψευσται have been falsely reported, D. 52.23; in E. Andr. 346 for ἀλλὰ ψεύσεται it will be falsely said, Porsonʼs correction ἐψεύσεται is probable ( πεύσεται Kiehl).

children.label: B
children.definition: ψεύδομαι, imper. ψεύδεο Il. 4.404 (the Act. is very rare in Att. Prose): fut. ψεύσομαι Hom., Pi., Att.: aor ἐψευσάμην, v. infr.: fut. 2 ἐψεύσομαι ( will have made a false statement) Gal. 15.137 (s. v.l.): pf. ἔψευσμαι X. An. 1.3.10.

children.label: I
children.definition: lie, speak false, play false, ψεύσομαι ἦ ἔτυμον ἐρέω; Il. 10.534, Od. 4.140; οὐκ οἶδα ψεύδεσθαι h.Merc. 369; οὐ ψεύσομʼ ἀμφὶ Κορίνθῳ Pi. O. 13.52; περί τινος Pl. Prt. 347a; ψ. κατά τινος, opp. λέγειν τἀληθῆ κατά τινος, Id. Euthd. 284a, Lys. 22.7; ψ. πρός τινα X. An. 1.3.5; ψ. τινι Act.Ap. 5.4 and εἴς τινα Ep.Col. 3.9.
inf., say falsely, pretend that . . , Plu. Garr. 2.506d.

say that which is untrue, whether intentionally or not, τοῦτό γʼ οὐκ ἐψεύσατο Ar. Ec. 445; οὐδὲν αὐτῶν ψεύδεται Id. Ach. 561; κἂν λάβῃς ἐψευσμένον, φάσκειν ἔμʼ ἤδη μαντικῇ μηδὲν φρονεῖν S. OT 461; ἐάν τι μὴ ἀληθὲς λέγω . . , εἰπὲ ὅτι τοῦτο ψεύδομαι· ἑκὼν γὰρ εἶναι οὐδὲν ψεύσομαι Pl. Smp. 214e, cf. X. Mem. 4.2.19; περὶ ὧν ἔψευσται διδάσκειν ὑμᾶς Lys. 3.21.

data.quote: κἂν λάβῃς ἐψευσμένον, φάσκειν ἔμʼ ἤδη μαντικῇ μηδὲν φρονεῖν
ἐάν τι μὴ ἀληθὲς λέγω . . , εἰπὲ ὅτι τοῦτο ψεύδομαι· ἑκὼν γὰρ εἶναι οὐδὲν ψεύσομαι

children.definition: to be false or faithless, to be perjured or forsworn, Hes. Op. 283.

ὁ ψευδόμενος, the Liar, name of a fallacy or logical puzzle invented by Eubulides, a disciple of Euclides of Megara, Thphr. ap. D.L. 2.108, cf. Chrysipp.Stoic. 2.92 ( ψευδόμενος is an interpolation in ὁ σοφιστικὸς λόγος ψ. Arist. EN 1146a22).

children.label: II
children.definition: Act. II, belie, falsify, ὅρκια ψεύσασθαι break them, Il. 7.352; so συνθήκας ψ. X. Ages. 1.12; γάμους E. Ba. 31, 245; so in plpf., ἔψευστο τὴν ξυμμαχίαν Th. 5.83; so also οὐκ ἐψεύσαντο τὰς ἀπειλάς they did not belie, i.e. they made good, their threats, Hdt. 6.32; τὰ χρήματα . . ἐψευσμένοι ἦσαν had broken their word about the money, X. An. 5.6.35.

children.label: III
children.definition: Act. I, deceive by lies, cheat, Λοξίαν ἐψευσάμην A. Ag. 1208, cf. X. HG 3.1.25; also ψ. τινά τι deceive one in a thing, S. OC 1145, E. Alc. 808; ἅπερ αὐτὸν οὐ ψεύσομαι and therein I will not disappoint him (ironical), i.e. I will carry out my threat, And. 1.123; τῶν ἔργων ὧν ἂν τὸν ἐκδόντα ψεύσηται ( ὧν being in gen. by attraction) Pl. Lg. 921a.

children.label: IV
children.definition: make a false statement, Arist. Int. 16a3.
false swearer, Lyc. 523.
falsely sworn, forsworn, ὅρκος Lyc. 932.

under a false name, falsely called, Ὑβριστὴν ποταμὸν οὐ ψευδώνυμον A. Pr. 717; πανδίκως ψ. Id. Th. 670; οὔνομα δʼ Εὐτυχίδης· ψευδώνυμον ἀλλά με δαίμων θῆκεν ἀφαρπάξας IG 3.1308; ψ. θεοί Ph. 2.161, cf. 2.599; ψ. γνῶσις 1 Ep.Ti. 6.21; φιλόσοφος ψευδεπίγραφος καὶ ψ. Plu. Frat. 2.479e; opp. ἀληθής, τὸ μεριστὸν ψ. Dam. Pr. 399. Adv. -μως by a false name, ψ. σε δαίμονες Προμηθέα καλοῦσιν A. Pr. 85, cf. Them. Or. 2.30a.

data.quote: οὔνομα δʼ Εὐτυχίδης· ψευδώνυμον ἀλλά με δαίμων θῆκεν ἀφαρπάξας

children.definition: hating falsehood, epith of Apollo, AP 9.525.24.
lie, untruth, fraud, εὐτυχέστατον ψεῦσμα ἐψευσμένος Pl. Men. 71d, cf. Luc. Tim. 55, Plu. Art. 13.

children.label: II
children.definition: τοὺς ἐπὶ τῆς ῥινὸς φυομένους ἰόνθους Σικελιῶται ψεύσματα ἔλεγον Sch. Theoc. 12.24, cf. Kaibel CGF p.218.
to be a liar, Il. 19.107.

liar, cheat, Il. 24.261; ἀνὴρ ψ. Hdt. 7.209, cf. LXX Si. 15.8: c. gen. rei, ὧν . . ψεῦσται φανούμεθα wherein we shall be found to be liars, S. Ant. 1195, cf. Arist. EN 1127b16, AP 12.70 ( Mel.), Phld. Herc. 1457.12.

Adj., = ψευδής, lying, false, ψ. λόγος Pi. N. 5.29; ψεύστης δʼ οτος ἔπεστι λίθος, of a cenotaph, AP 7.273 ( Leon.); τὸν ψεύσταν δέ με τύμβον . . θέντο· τί θαῦμα; Κρῆτες ὅπου ψεῦσται, καὶ Διός ἐστι τάφος ib. 275 ( Gaet.), alluding to Κρῆτες ἀεὶ ψεῦσται, Epimenid. 1, which is cited by Call. Jov. 8, Ep.Tit. 1.12.
fallacia, dub. in Gloss.
mendacious, Vett.Val. 17.31.
ψεύστης, νύξ Epigr.Gr. 418 ( Cyrene).

definition: ψεφαίαις σκοτειναῖς, and ψεφαῖον· λυπρόν, σκοτεινόν, Hsch.

children.definition: gloomy, cloudy, Hp. ap. Gal. 19.156 (v.l. for ὑποψ- in Hp. Prorrh. 1.116).
gloom, darkness, Pi. Fr. 324.
dark, obscure, metaph. of a person, Pi. N. 3.41 codd. ( -εινός Bgk., -εννός Pors.).
darkness, cj. Lobeck in Alc. 112 ( ψόφου, σκότου codd.), cf. Gal. 19.156; = καπνός, Hsch.

definition: ψέφω, in 3 sg. ψέφει· δέδοικεν, ἐντρέπει, λυπεῖ, φροντίζει, Hsch.: cf. μετα-ψέφω; also prob. ἐπί-σσοφος.

children.definition: EM 818.2. ψῇ, v. ψάω.

that which is rubbed or scraped off, shavings, scrapings, chips, ψ. χρυσοῦ gold- dust, Hdt. 4.195; so without χρυσοῦ, Id. 1.93, 3.94 sq.; ψ. χρυσότευκτον Eub. 20; ψ. ἀργυρᾶ Inscr.Délos 442 B 89 (ii B.C.); πυρωθὲν ψ., of dust and ashes, A. Ag. 442 (lyr.); of wood, τὰ τῶν αἰγείρων ψ. Philostr. Im. 1.11; ἥλων ψ., = χαλκοῦ ἄνθος, Dsc. 5.77; μὴ διαλύεσθαι μέχρι ἐλαχίστου ψήγματος (of gum) Id. 3.22; of motes in a sunbeam, Arist. Cael. 313a20, cf. 304a21, Plu. QConv. 2.722a, and v. τίλα II.

definition: ψηγμάτιον, τό, Dim. of foreg., Inscr.Délos 1429 B ii 17 (ii B.C.), Placit. 1.13.2.

children.definition: Hsch.
filled only level with the brim, i.e. not heaped up ( κορυστός), Gloss.
curry-comb for horses, S. Fr. 475, E. Hipp. 1174, Ar. Fr. 62, AP 6.233 ( Maec.), 246 ( Phld. or Marc.Arg.), PSI 4.430.5 (iii B.C.), etc. In Hsch. also ψακτήρ and (as glosses on ξύστρα)
scrape down, rub down, Sch. E. Hipp. 110.

definition: ψηκτρίον, τό, Dim. of ψήκτρα, Gloss. (in form ψηκτριν).
ψηλαφάω, mostly used in pres.: fut. -ήσω LXX Za. 9.13: aor. ἐψηλάφησα ib. Ge. 27.22:— Pass., fut. ψηλαφηθήσομαι ib. Na. 3.1: aor. ἐψηλαφήθην S.E. M. 8.108, Plu. Exil. 2.599c:—

children.definition: feel or grope about to find a thing, like a blind man or hoodman-blind, χερσὶ ψηλαφόων ( Ep. for -άων), of the Cyclops when blinded, Od. 9.416; ψηλαφῶν οὐκ ἐδυνάμην εὑρεῖν [τὸ ἱμάτιον] Ar. Ec. 315; ψηλαφῶντες . . ὥσπερ ἐν σκότει Pl. Phd. 99b: metaph., ψ. περί τινων Phld. D. 1.14.
feel about for, grope or search after, ἐψηλαφῶμεν ἐν σκότῳ τὰ πράγματα Ar. Pax 691; εἰ . . ψηλαφήσειαν αὐτὸν (sc. τὸν θεὸν) καὶ εὕροιεν Act.Ap. 17.27.

children.label: II
children.definition: feel, touch, handle, stroke, Poll. 1.183; μή ποτε ψηλαφήσῃ με ὁ πατήρ, of Isaac and Jacob, LXX Ge. 27.12, cf. Ev.Luc. 24.39; ψ. καὶ τρίβειν τοῖς δακτύλοις Arist. HA 571a33; esp. in Medic., of uterine examination, Hp. Mul. 1.40, al.:— Pass., ὧν ψηλαφωμένων ὁ ἵππος . . ἥδεται X. Eq. 2.4; [ ὄρνιθες] τῇ χειρὶ ψηλαφώμεναι Arist. HA 560a9.

children.label: III
children.definition: test, examine, τὸν ν Plb. 8.29.8; τὸν οἶνον Gp. 7.5.1; πᾶσαν ἐπίνοιαν Plb. 8.16.4; τὰς ἀλλήλων νοήσεις οἷον ὑπὸ σκότῳ διὰ φωνῆς ψ. Plu. Gen.Socr. 2.589b; εἴδωλον [τοῦ καλοῦ] διώκοντες καὶ ψ. ib. Amat. 766a:— Pass., S.E. l.c., τὰ ψηλαφηθέντα ὑπʼ Ἀντιόχου the attempts made by . . , J. AJ 13.9.2.

data.quote: τὰς ἀλλήλων νοήσεις οἷον ὑπὸ σκότῳ διὰ φωνῆς ψ.

children.definition: touch, Ph. 1.597; caress, X. Smp. 8.23.
feeling, touching, palpation, Hp. Steril. 213, al., Epicur. Fr. 21 (pl.), LXX Wi. 15.15, Plu. Aem. 14; tickling, αἱ τῶν μασχαλῶν ψ. Plu. Sanit. 2.125c, cf. Vind. 547b (pl.).
one must feel, handle, Archig. ap. Aët. 6.3.
one who feels, a searcher, Sch. Opp. H. 2.435.
by way of feeling, Eust. 1717.16.
that can be felt, σκότος LXX Ex. 10.21 (so ψηλαφῆσαι σκότος ib. Jb. 12.25).
touching, Hp. Decent. 8, Phld. D. 1.13, Aret. CA 1.1, Ruf. ap. Orib. inc. 2.30; handling, οὐ πολλῆς ψ. δεῖσθαι Ph. Bel. 56.33.
Anaxil. 44.
blind-manʼs-buff, Phryn. PS p.128B ( -ίνδρα cod.).
like one feeling or groping in the dark, of the gestures of delirious persons, Hp. Prorrh. 1.109.

definition: ψήληκες τῶν ἀλεκτρυόνων οἱ νοθογένναι, Hsch. ( ψήλικες cod.), Suid.

children.definition: gall-insect, Cynips psenes, which lives in the fruit of the wild fig and male palm, Hdt. 1.193, Ar. Av. 590 (anap.), Arist. HA 557b26, Thphr. HP 2.8.1.
fruit of the made palm, Poll. 1.244.
οὐδεὶς κομήτης ὅστις οὐ ψηνίζεται Com.Adesp. 12.

children.label: II
children.definition: to Psenize, alluding to the ψῆνες, a Comedy by Magnes so called, Ar. Eq. 523 (anap.).
bald headed, Semon. 40: cf. ψανός· ψεδνός, Hsch. (prob. ᾱ and Dor., Aeol., or Arc.-Cypr.).
rubbing down, currying, of horses, X. Eq. 5.3, 10.

definition: ψήρ, ὁ, gen. ψηρός, Ion. for ψάρ (q. v.).

children.definition: Hsch.
Suid.; cf. μεσ<σ>όψηρον, and perh. ψαρός (B).

definition: ψησσίον, τό, Dim. of ψῆσσα (v. ψῆττα), Zonar.

children.definition: flat-fish, prob. turbot, Rhombus maximus, Ar. Lys. 115, 131, Pl. Smp. 191d, Antiph. 132.7 (anap.), Ath. 7.329e, Luc. Pisc. 49, Alciphr. 1.7; ψ. χονδροφυής perh. a skate, Matro Conv. 27.

children.label: II
children.definition: a glutton, Pl.Com. 106. (The form ψῆσσα Alex.Trall. 1.15, al., Zonar.; ψησία (s. v. l.) Suid.)

definition: ψηττάριον [ᾰ], τό, Dim. of ψῆττα, Anaxandr. 27 (anap., ψιτταδίοις cod.A. Ath., corr. Lobeck).

children.definition: like a flat-fish, Arist. IA 714a6.
turbot-footed, name of a fabulous people in Luc. VH 1.35.

definition: ψηφηφορέω, ψηφη-φορία, later forms of ψηφοφ-.

children.definition: a little pebble, Iamb. Myst. 3.17 (v.l. ψηφίδων gen. pl.).
pebbly, stony, γῆ Gp. 2.6.41, al.

definition: ψηφίζω, fut. Att. -ιῶ ( ἐπι-) Aeschin. 2.84: aor. ἐψήφισα Plu. Coniug. 2.141c, ( ἐπι-) Th. 2.24: pf. ἐψήφικα ( ἐπ-) X. An. 5.6.35, ( κατ-) D.H. 5.8:— Med., v. infr. ΙΙ:— Pass., v. infr. ΙΙΙ:—

children.definition: count, reckon, prop. with pebbles ( ψῆφοι), Plb. 5.26.13, AP 11.168 ( Antiphan.), 171 ( Lucill.); ψ. δακτύλοις Plu. l.c.
ἐὰν ψηφίσῃς τὸ ἓν ἐν γράμμασιν, i.e. if you add up the numerical values of the letters in the word ἕν, Theol.Ar. 64.

children.label: II
children.definition: Med. ψηφίζομαι: fut. Att. ψηφιοῦμαι Ar. V. 769, Th. 7.48, Pl. Smp. 177d, etc. ( ψηφίσομαι is f.l. where found, e.g. in Lys. 12.44, 14.47, ( κατα-) Antipho 1.12, 6.10, ( ἀπο-) ibid.): aor. ἐψηφισάμην Hdt. 5.97, Th. 7.48, etc.: pf. ἐψήφισμαι in med. sense, Ar. V. 591 (anap.), Th. 1.120, etc.:—prop., cast oneʼs vote with a pebble:
εἰς ὑδρίαν ψ. X. HG 1.7.9, cf. Ar. V. 755 (anap.): generally, vote, ψήφῳ ψηφίζεσθαι μὴ φεύγειν Hdt. 9.55; τοῖς νόμοις ψηφίσασθαι vote in support of the laws, D. 21.188; ἐναντία ψ. τινι Pl. Smp. 177d.

vote for, carry by vote, τὸν πόλεμον Th. 1.86; ψηφίσασθαί τινι τὸν πλοῦν vote him the voyage, Id. 4.29; ψ. παρασκευήν Id. 6.25, cf. Ar. Lys. 951; ἐπιβολὴν ψ. Id. V. 769; δίκην Is. 3.7; ἄδειαν And. 1.12; διαδίκασμα ψ. τινι Lys. 17.10; κλῆρόν τινι ψ. to adjudge it to . . , D. 43.6: c. dupl. acc., ψ. τινα θεόν vote him a god, Plu. Apophth.reg. 2.187e.

inf., vote, resolve to do something, c. inf. pres., ψ. μένειν Hdt. 7.207, cf. 9.55 (supr. cit.); ψ. τι δρᾶν A. Ag. 1353: c. inf. aor., ψ. νέας ἀποστεῖλαι Hdt. 5.97, cf. Ar. V. 591 (anap.), Pl. Grg. 516e: c. inf. fut., ψ. πάντας ἀποσφάξειν (better ἀποσφάξαι as cod. P) D.S. 12.72: c. acc. et inf., vote that . . , ψ. τὰς σπονδὰς λελύσθαι Th. 1.88; ψ. ὥστε μὴ ἴσων ἕκαστον τυγχάνειν X. Cyr. 2.2.20: ψ. ὅπως τις ἄρχοι μόνος Plu. Pomp. 54.

data.quote: ψ. ὥστε μὴ ἴσων ἕκαστον τυγχάνειν

children.definition: ψ. περί, ὑπέρ τινος, Pl. Demod. 382d, Aeschin. 1.154.

children.label: III
children.definition: Act. is used in signf. decide by vote, δίκην κατʼ ἄλλου . . ἐψήφισαν S. Aj. 449, and is also found in IGRom. 4.293a ii 57 ( Pergam., ii B.C.); ψηφίζομεν is dub. in Hdn. 2.3.4 ( ἐπευφημίζομεν Schwartz):— Pass., aor. ψηφισθῆναι be voted, τοῖς στρατηγοῖς εἴ του προσδέοιντο ψηφισθῆναι ἐς τὸν ἔκπλουν Th. 6.8; τὸ ψήφισμα ἐψηφίσθη Lys. 13.29; τὰ ψηφισθέντα πλοῖα X. HG 1.2.1: fut., τὰ ψηφισθησόμενα Isoc. 6.92: pf., ἐψηφισμένοι θανεῖν condemned by vote, E. Heracl. 141; τοῖς ἰχθυοπώλαις ἐστὶν ἐψηφισμένον . . στῆσαι Alex. 56.

data.quote: τοῖς στρατηγοῖς εἴ του προσδέοιντο ψηφισθῆναι ἐς τὸν ἔκπλουν

children.definition: involving calculations, Vett.Val. 191.30, al.

made of marble, λίθινος ἢ ψ. μυροθήκη as expl. of ἀλάβαστρον, AB 374: ἀλάβαστρον· μυροθήκη λίθος ψήφινος, Hsch. ( λίθινος ἢ ψ. Cyr.): ἀπὸ Ἁρποκράτου ψηφίνου from a marble (statue of) Harpocrates, PMag.Par. 1.1074.
Dim. of ψῆφος, small pebble, gravel, Aq. Am. 9.9; pellet, μέλιτος Orib. Fr. 35 (pl.).
Dim. of ψῆφος, small pebble, Il. 21.260, Lex Solonis ap.Sch.Gen.Il. l.c., Democr. 164, Luc. DMar. 3.2.
pebble for reckoning, AP 11.365 ( Agath.).
tessellated work, Chor. p.86B. [1.2.29]

children.label: II
children.definition: gem or amulet worn in a ring, Longus4.17, Alex.Trall. 11.1.
voting, only in Locr. acc. sg. ψάφιξξιν [ᾱ], IG 9 (1).334.45 (Oeanthea, v. B.C.).

definition: ψήφισμα, ατος, τό, Dor. ψάφιγμα [ψᾱ] Inscr.Cret. 1. v 20 A 17 ( Arcades, ii B.C.); written [ ψ]άπιγμα Supp.Epigr. 4.171.53 ( Tymnus, v/iv B.C.):—

children.definition: proposal passed by a majority of votes: esp. measure passed by a popular assembly, decree, act, A. Supp. 601 (pl.), Ar. Ach. 536, al.: c. gen. suasoris, the decree proposed by him, τὸ Καννωνοῦ ψ. Id. Ec. 1090, cf. And. 1.27: but τὸ Μεγαρέων ψ. the decree concerning them, Th. 1.140 (more freq. τὸ περὶ Μ. ψ. ib. 139, cf. X. HG 2.1.32); also τὸ ψ. τὸ διὰ τὰς λαικαστρίας Ar. Ach. 536; ἐγένετο ψ. μὴ ἐξεῖναι . . X. HG 2.2.15; ψ. γράφειν bring in a decree, Ar. Nu. 1429; ψ. ἐπιψηφίζειν put it to the vote, Aeschin. 2.84; ψ. νικᾶν carry it, Id. 3.68; ψ. καθαιρεῖν rescind it, Th. 1.140; ἐξαλεῖψαι, ἀφελέσθαι, And. 1.76, 2.24: prop. concerned with special circumstances ( οὐδὲν ἐνδέχεται ψ. εἶναι καθόλου Arist. Pol. 1292a37); opp. νόμος (general law, statute), νόμους καὶ ψηφίσματα Pl. Tht. 173d; ὅταν τὰ ψ. κύρια ᾖ ἀλλὰ μὴ ὁ νόμος Arist. Pol. 1292a6; περὶ ἐνίων ἀδύνατον θέσθαι νόμον, ὥστε ψηφίσματος δεῖ Id. EN 1137b29; ψηφισμάτων οὐδʼ ὁτιοῦν διαφέρουσιν οἱ νόμοι, ἀλλὰ νεώτεροι οἱ νόμοι, καθʼ οὓς τὰ ψ. δεῖ γράφεσθαι, τῶν ψ. αὐτῶν D. 20.92.

data.quote: τὸ ψ. τὸ διὰ τὰς λαικαστρίας
ὅταν τὰ ψ. κύρια ᾖ ἀλλὰ μὴ ὁ νόμος
περὶ ἐνίων ἀδύνατον θέσθαι νόμον, ὥστε ψηφίσματος δεῖ
ψηφισμάτων οὐδʼ ὁτιοῦν διαφέρουσιν οἱ νόμοι, ἀλλὰ νεώτεροι οἱ νόμοι, καθʼ οὓς τὰ ψ. δεῖ γράφεσθαι, τῶν ψ. αὐτῶν

children.label: II
children.definition: decree, law, θεῶν ψ. παλαιόν Emp. 115, cf. Ar. V. 378 (lyr.), Lex ap. And. 1.96, LXX Es. 3.7, al.
one who drives a traffic in ψηφίσματα, Ar. Av. 1037; also ψηφισμᾰτο-γράφος [ᾰ], ὁ, Arg. Ar. Av.
of the nature of a ψήφισμα, Arist. EN 1134b24.
the use of pebbles (in casting lots), διὰ ψηφισμοῦ ᾑρημένος as gloss on ἀπὸ τοῦ κυάμου, Sch. Th. 8.69.
one must calculate, Vett.Val. 33.31.
calculator, Cat. Cod.Astr. 2.178 (pl.).
dice-box, Suid. s.v. τάβλα.
pebbly, Thphr. Lap. 47.
laying of a mosaic pavement, Inscr. gr. et lat. de la Syrie 1.168 ( Nicopolis, ii/iii A.D.).

maker of tessellated pavements, Gloss.; written ψηφοδ[έ]τας in Epigr.Gr. 532 ( Perinthus):—hence ψηφο-θετέω, make such work, JRS 18.171 ( Gerasa), Gloss.; and ψηφοθέτημα, ατος, τό, the work itself, ib.
box for counters or ballots, Sch. Ar. Th. 1040.
account-board, Ar. Fr. 348.
LXX To. 13.17 ( Pass.):—hence ψηφο-λόγημα, ατος, τό, Hero *Stereom. 2.35, Lyd. Mag. 3.65 (pl.), Explor.Arch. de Délos 11.261 (pl.); ψηφο-λογία, ἡ,
juggling, Suid., f.l. in EM 535.1.
playing juggling tricks, juggler, Suid.
play juggling tricks, Artem. 3.55.
ψ. τὸ δίκαιον juggle away right, Lys. Fr. 17.
one who juggles with pebbles, Eudox.Com. 1, S.E. P. 2.250.
juggling, legerdemain, sleight-of-hand, Gloss.
jar of pebbles used as a rattle (?), dub. sens. in Eub. 56.
making votes or tampering with them, κλέπτης γὰρ αὐτοῦ ψηφοποιὸς εὑρέθης S. Aj. 1135.

definition: ψῆφος, Dor. ψᾶφος, Aeol. ψᾶφαξ, ἡ, gen. pl. ψηφάων Man. 4.448: ( ψάω):—

children.definition: a small round worn stone, pebble, ψᾶφος ἑλισσομένα Pi. O. 10(11).9; οὐκ ἂν εἰδείην λέγειν ποντιᾶν ψάφων ἀριθμόν ib. 13.46; ψήφῳ μούνῃ διατετρανέεις, opp. μόγις ἂν λίθῳ παίσας διαρρήξειας, Hdt. 3.12; ψ. ἄμμου a grain of sand, LXX Si. 18.10.
precious stone, gem, Philostr. VA 3.27; esp. worn in a ring, Luc. DMeretr. 9.

pebble used for reckoning, counter, λογίζεσθαι ψήφοις calculate or reckon by abacus, cipher, Hdt. 2.36, etc.: hence to reckon exactly or accurately, opp. ἀπὸ χειρὸς λ., Ar. V. 656 (anap.); οὐ τιθεὶς ψήφους D. 18.229; ἐν ψήφῳ λέγειν A. Ag. 570; ἐν ψήφου λόγῳ θέσθαι E. Rh. 309: metaph., ταῖς τοῦ συμφέροντος ψήφοις μετρεῖν τὰς ἔχθρας καὶ τὰς φιλίας Plb. 2.47.5: hence ψῆφος itself for a cipher, number, πὸτ ἄρτιον (sc. ἀριθμὸν) ποτθέμειν . . ψᾶφον Epich. 170: pl., accounts, καθαραὶ ψ., where there is an exact balance, D. 18.227; οἱ περὶ τὰς ψ. calculators, Alciphr. 1.26; ψήφων ἄπειρος Plu. Praec. 2.812e; δακτυλικὴ ψ. reckoning on the fingers, AP 11.290 ( Pall.); of astrological calculations, Vett.Val. 10.15, al.

data.quote: ταῖς τοῦ συμφέροντος ψήφοις μετρεῖν τὰς ἔχθρας καὶ τὰς φιλίας

children.label: b
children.definition: κατέχων τὴν ψ. (i. e. the object on which the number is written) λέγε . . PMag.Par. 1.1048, cf. 937.
pebble used for a draughts- or chess-man, Pl. R. 487c; κύβος ἐν παιδιᾷ ψήφων Plu. Def.orac. 2.427f.

children.label: b
children.definition: pebble used by jugglers, ψηφάων παῖκται Man. 4.448.
pebble used in divination, ἡ διὰ ψήφων μαντική Apollod. 3.10.2.
cube used in mosaic pavements, Gal. Protr. 8.

pebble used in voting, ψήφῳ ψηφίζεσθαι Hdt. 9.55; ἐὰν μὴ τῇ ψ . . . ψηφίσωνται κρύβδην ψηφιζόμενοι D. 59.89: hence, the vote itself, ψῆφον φέρειν give oneʼs vote, ἐν καρδίᾳ ψ. φέροντες A. Eu. 680, cf. And. 1.2, D. 57.61, etc.; ὑπέρ τινος Lycurg. 7; περί τινος Id. 11, etc.; ψήφου φορά E. Supp. 484; ψῆφον τίθεσθαι, = ψηφίζεσθαι, Hdt. 8.123, cf. 6.57; εἰς τεῦχος . . ψήφους ἔθεντο A. Ag. 816; c. inf., Hdt. 3.73; ψ. προσθέσθαι Th. 1.40; ψήφῳ διαιρεῖν to determine by vote, A. Eu. 630; ψήφῳ κρίνειν, Th. 1.87, etc.; μεταλαβὼν τὸ πέμπτον μέρος τῶν ψ. Pl. Ap. 36b, cf. Lex ap. D. 21.47: in collect. sense, ἐχρῆν . . ψ. περὶ αὐτοῦ γενέσθαι a vote is taken, Antipho 5.47; ἡ καθαιροῦσα ψ. Lys. 13.37; ἡ σῴζουσα ψ. D. 19.66; οἷς ἂν πλείστη γένηται ψ. a majority of votes, Pl. Lg. 759d: τὴν ψῆφον ἐπάγειν to put the vote or question, of the president, Th. 1.119, 125; ψῆφον δοῦναι περί τινος IG 2(2).222.24, cf. D. 21.188; ψ. ἀναδοὺς περί τινος App. BC 1.100; so ψ. περὶ ἡμῶν ὑπὲρ ἀνδραποδισμοῦ προτεθεῖσαν D. 19.65; διένεμον (vv. ll. διενέμοντο, ἔφερον) τὰς ψ. were casting their votes, Hdt. 8.123; ὑπὸ ψήφου μιᾶς with one accord, Ar. Lys. 270; ψ. φανερά open voting, ψ. φανερὰν διενεγκεῖν Th. 4.74; τὴν ψ. οὐκ εἰς καδίσκους ἀλλὰ φανερὰν ἐπὶ τὰς τραπέζας τίθεσθαι Lys. 13.37, cf. Pl. Lg. 767d, 855d; opp. ψ. ἀφανής voting by ballot, Aeschin. 3.233; κρύβδην τὴν ψ. φέρειν Arist. Rh.Al. 1433a23, cf. 1424b2, Ath. 69.1.

P. 4.265; ψ. φλεγυρὰ βροτῶν, i.e. public opinion, Cratin. 57 (lyr.); τίνʼ ἂν ψῆφον θεῖο; what judgement . . ? Pl. Prt. 330c, cf. R. 450a; ἡ ἐμὴ ψ. Id. Phlb. 57a.

children.definition: Ἀθηνᾶς ψ., calculus Minervae, prov. phrase to express acquittal, when the votes were even, Philostr. VS 2.3.

children.label: f

children.label: g
children.definition: Κόννου ψ., negligible quantity, cipher, Ar. V. 675 (anap.), cf. Κοννᾶς.
place of voting, tribunal, E. IT 945, El. 1263.
influence, πόλις μεγάλην ψ. ἔχουσα Lib. Or. 18.13.
give oneʼs vote, vote, D.H. 4.20, Luc. Tim. 36, S.E. M. 2.40; determine by vote, ὅστις ἡγήσεται Phld. Acad.Ind. p.38M.

vote by ballot, Arist. Pol. 1268a2; opp. χειροτονία, Id. Rh.Al. 1446b22: generally, voting, Foed.Delph.Pell. 1A 12, Phld. Rh. 2.189S., D.H. 4.20, 7.59, Plu. Cor. 20, etc.; αἱ ὑπατικαὶ ψ. voting at the consular comitia, Id. Marc. 4.
judgement, decree, θεοῦ J. AJ 4.2.4.
calculation, Ptol. Alm. 4.9 (pl.), Procl. Hyp. 1.27, etc.:—sts. written ψηφηφορία, as in Arist. Rh.Al. l.c.
voting, ἐκκλησία D.H. 7.59; = suffragator, Gloss.
adorn with gems, τοὺς πόδας Lyd. Mag. 1.4, cf. Mens. 1.26.

ready reckoner, Man. 5.277 (dub.; v.l. ψηφών).
Gloss.
inlaid with ψῆφοι, tessellated, Keil-Premerstein Dritter Bericht No. 117 ( Tire, i A. D.), Gloss.
ground fine, Hsch., Suid.

stroke, ψήχων δέρην μέτωπά τʼ E. Hel. 1567; φαρμάκῳ ἔψηχεν θηρὸς κάρη A.R. 4.164.
scratch, dub. in Jul. Caes. 310a.

Hsch.
like rush-mats to expl. φορμηδόν, Sch. Th. 2.75, Suid.
lie on a mat, Hierocl. Facet. 107.

Dim. of ψίαθος, Philem. 26, interpol. in Dsc. 5.88: perh. rush basket, ψιέθιν (sic) ψωμίων ᾱ POxy. 1923.7 (v/vi A. D.): τὰ αἱροῦν<τα> ὑμῖν ψιάθια ( ψαίθια Pap.) εἰς τὸν κατανγισμὸν τοῦ ἄνθρακος PBaden 29.7 (v A. D.).

a plaiter of mats, PSI 10.1132.8 (i A. D.), Greg. Cor. p.551S., Lex.Herodot. ap.Stein Herodotus ii p.458, Suid. s.v. σχοίνου συμβολεῖς: written ψαθοπλόκος in Sammelb. 5124.332 ( Tebtunis, ii A. D.):—also ψῐᾰθ-ποιός, ὁ, Gloss.

definition: ψίαθος [ῐ], ἡ (also ὁ, read by Callistr. in Ar. Ra. 567, cf. Sch. ad loc. ( 575)), also ψίεθος, Antig. Mir. 97, Ostr.Bodl. iii 228 (i A. D.), etc. (condemned by Phryn. 281):—

like a mat, Eust. 1344.45, Sch. Ar. Ach. 72, etc.

definition: ψίαι ἀλώπεκες, Hsch. (cf. ψύα); also ψειαί· ἀλώπεκες, ψῆφοι, Id. ψῐαίνω, aor. inf. ψιῆναι· ψίξαι, Id., Suid. ( ψέξαι codd.); cf. σιαίνω.

drop, αἱματοέσσας δὲ ψιάδας κατέχευεν ἔραζε (sc. Ζεύς) Il. 16.459, cf. Hes. Sc. 384: also ψίαξ, ακος, (pl.), Hsch.; cf. ψίδες.

ψιδόνες διάβολοι, ψίθυροι Hsch.; cf. ψυθῶνες.

ἄσκαρος, Poll. 4.60; ψιθυρᾶν μάλʼ αἰολᾶν S. Inach. fr. 269c**.32 Radt (lyr.).
whisper, Pl. Grg. 485e; πρός τινα Id. Euthd. 276d, Duris 69J.; ἀλλήλοις Theoc. 27.68.

whisper ( i.e. rustle), ὁπόταν πλάτανος πτελέᾳ ψιθυρίζῃ Ar. Nu. 1008 (anap.); also of swallows, twitter, Poll. 5.90.
whispering, ψ. τὸ ναυτικόν AP 9.546 ( Antiphil.); δόλια ψ. ib. 3.3 (Inscr.Cyzic.).

whispering, Phld. Ir. p.55 W., Luc. Am. 15; πρός τινα Plu. Aud. 2.45d, etc.
slandering, ib. Coniug. 143f, 2 Ep.Cor. 12.20 (pl.).

slanderer, Ep.Rom. 1.30.
slanderous, τὸ ψ. Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(2).33.

Ar. Fr. 891.
Paus. 3.19.6; he explains it as winged (from ψίλον Dor. for πτίλον), which suggests that it has ῐ.

armlet, IG 11(2).161 B 26, 162 B 15, 199 B 57, 203 B 82 ( Delos, iii B. C.), Inscr.Délos 296 B 37 (iii B. C.); ψιλίον (sic): . . ψέλλιον, Hsch.; also ψίλλιον IG ΙΙ(2).203 A 4 (iii B. C.): v. ψίδιον.

to be bald-headed, Diog. Ep. 19.

bald-headed, Tz.ad Hes. Op. 374.

X. An. 1.5.5, etc.: in full, [ γῆ] ψ. δενδρέων Hdt. 4.19, 21; ἄδενδρα καὶ ψ., of the Alps, Plb. 3.55.9; τὰ ψ. (sc. χωρία), opp. τὰ ὑλώδη, X. Cyn. 5.7; τόποι ψ. ib. 4.6; ψ. γεωργία the tillage of land for corn and the like, opp. γ. πεφυτευμένη (the tillage of it for vines, olives, etc.), Arist. Pol. 1258b18, Thphr. CP 3.20.1; so γῆ ψ. Eup. 230, D. 20.115, Tab.Heracl. 1.175, 2.33; ἐλαῖαι, ὧν νῦν τὰ πολλὰ ἐκκέκοπται καὶ ἡ γῆ ψ. γεγένηται Lys. 7.7.

Th. 227; ψ. γνάθοι ib. 583; τὴν ὀσφὺν κομιδῇ ψ. Pherecr. 23.4 (anap.); used of dogs with a short, smooth coat of hair, X. Cyn. 3.2; τὴν δίποδα ἀγέλην τῷ ψ. καὶ τῷ πτεροφυεῖ τέμνειν Pl. Plt. 266e; ἄνθρωπος -ότατον κατὰ τὸ σῶμα τῶν ζῴων πάντων ἐστί Arist. GA 745b16; so ἶβις ψ. τὴν κεφαλήν without feathers, bald on the head, Hdt. 2.76; hairless, of the foetus of a hare, Id. 3.108; ψ. τὰ περὶ τὴν κεφαλήν, of the ostrich, Arist. PA 697b18.
